content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												So I've played Victoria II + expansions (AHD and HOD) for a bit (mostly POP demand mod) and I'm certainly no grand master of strategy or anything, but there are still a ton of things that annoy to no end about this game. They annoy me so much I've decided to write this entire rant about them. My experiences with these kind of games are rather limited, I've played HoI 2 like 70 years ago quite a lot and HoI 3 only for about 10 minutes cause I ♥♥♥♥ing hate sliders. Otherwise I've played some of the older Total War games and Civ games (including Civ 5) but I can't really compare this game to Crusader Kings 2 oder EU 4 or something. I'm just some guy on the internet so I have honestly no idea how to systematically review things so I'll just name things as they come to mind.So first, what exactly is this game trying to be? It's trying to be rather historically accurate but at the same time... it's not. When compared to the mass of events you have in HoI, the game feels really empty. That is understandable as HoI covers a much shorter time range and allows for a more historical simulation. But did really so little happen during those 100 years that most events you have are just random events during elections and such? I wish there were more events that influence my relations with neighbouring countries and such. But instead, everyone is just sitting there and I'm only increasing or decreasing my relations over the diplomacy screen. Lame. At the same time, it's like the game is discouraging 'unhistorical' conquest. Why do I get a massive hit for administrative effenciency (or whatever it's called) for a state just because it's not a 'core' area of my country? You'd think after 50 years of something, people would get used to being citizens of my country, but nope. You don't even have any way of influencing core areas.As usual, the tutorials suck. They show you every screen of the game once and that's about it. What is it with these kind of games and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ tutorials? This game was released in 2010, do they still expect players to read through the manual (100 damn pages)? Tell me the most important stuff during the tutorial or have useful tooltips during the game, damn it. It's not like in League of Legends or similar games where most knowledge is meta stuff that you learn as you play, so it's not like it would be entirely impossible to have a decent tutorial. What research should I focus on? What should my army composition look like? What do all the stats a general has mean? Well, good luck finding out.The AI sucks. They are incredibly hesistant when it comes to alliances but they will allow basically everyone and their mom military access to their country. Yeah right. It's almost as if borders don't particularly matter. They are also incredibly incompetent when it comes to managing an uncivilized country (or unciv as the community calls them). So don't expect anything from AI controlled uncivs in this game. You'd expect them to wage wars against each other and try to become a relevant country in their area. But instead they just sit there, eventually going bankrupt. Would a decent AI for unvics be too much to ask for? The fact that those countries never manage to do anything really takes away from the game.Also the AI is just so incredibly stupid when it comes to leading wars. Unlike in HoI, you can't just declare war on a country. You always need a casus belli (CB) to declare war on someone and if you don't have one, you gotta make one. But making one risks you getting caught which results in you getting infamy (which gets reduces each month) and a lot of infamy is bad (like unrest in HoI). You'd think the AI uses their infamy wisely to press their advantage, but nope. They often just sit there with 0 infamy. But at the same time, when they do have a CB, they will often go to war even when it's complete suicide. You'd think the AI would be competent enough to calculate whether they can win a war or not, but nope. So Germany goes to war against France and gets their♥♥♥♥♥handed to them for no real reason. Over and over.Naval units suck. The game only simulates a global market rather than local markets or supply lines so you can't block a country from trading or anything. Hey Paradox, ever heard the term 'Pax Britannica'? Why can't ships support your land units or anything? During that time, a superpower without a strong fleet would have been unthinkable. But according to this game, all you need is a strong land army to beat your neighbours over and over. Also, is a global market really realistic? I mean sure, the superpowers probably had plenty of international trade going on, but did all the backwards Asian countries or small European countries really trade on a global scale? I can't believe that. You'd think a game about a time where a strong fleet was basically the most important thing in the world would concentrate on forcing the player to play along, but nope.The economy is so hard to follow. Why are the production and trade screen seperate? You know, seeing how much stuff I produce and how much is traded (supply/demand) is sometimes important to know so why not just have it on one screen? Doesn't make any sense. It's also hard to understand why your factories aren't selling all their stuff. What's the problem with not selling everything anyway? You'd think they can just store some of their productions and sell it later when demand is higher. But nope. Apparently furniture unsold gets thrown away or something. And why can't the game tell me in a coherent way how much demand for a certain good exists in my own damn country, so I'd know if it's worth producing something myself or not. And sort the goods in some alphabetical order or something. Sometimes you're just searching your♥♥♥♥♥off looking for something.Land battle simulation sucks. You know, in HoI, a lot goes into decent planning of an invasion. Not crossing rivers for an attack. Not attacking with too many units from one area (cause generals have a limited number of units they can command, everything beyond is ineffective). Not attacking during winter. Not going for a naval invasion when there are units defending an area. Not trying to do a huge attack in some mountain area. You know, all that kind of stuff that you have to consider in real life. But in Victoria 2, forget all that and just throw your armies together into one big battle! All you need are some good dice rolls and you win. The dice rolls♥♥♥♥♥♥me off so much. I mean, imagine in Starcraft, a zergling wouldn't hit for 5 damage with every attack. Instead the game rolled a dice for damage between 1 and 10. That's what it's like in this game. I always thought Napoleon or other figures had such outstanding military success because of their superior military strategies or whatever, but according to this game, he probably just had good dice rolls.The recruitment system sucks. I like the idea that I can't form units with soldiers of different nationality, but why can't certain religions mix? I guess the game just didn't have a way to deal with that so that kinda sucks. And what's with all the soldiers I have in my empire that aren't enough to form a unit? What do they do all day? Nothing? And what happens when I disband a unit that doesn't have a POP large enough to support them? I can't re-recruit them, so where do all the soldiers go? Do they just disappear? I don't get it.Oh well, I could rant on and on about things I don't like in this game, but nobody is ever going to read it all anyway. So screw that. I guess it's only really fun in multiplayer.

												Victoria 2, yet another Grand Strategy produced by Paradox Interactive, however unlike Europa Universalis taking you through the Early-Modern period, Hearts of Iron taking you through the second world war, Victoria 2 takes you through the Victorian era, a period of colonization, Nationalism, Industrialization, and Westernization.You play as Literally any country from 1836, from the United States of Central America to the Free City of Kraków, and guide it through the Industrial era and the Victorian era.Forge your destiny as you Guide your nation through 100 years of industrialization, war, and colonization, vie for Great Power Status and sign Alliances that at a split second, could be aimed at you, survive anarcho-liberal uprisings and anti-western Partisans as you try to Westernize as Japan.Along with nations that already exist, there are some that are relasable or formable; defeat the Russian Empire as Sweden and Form Scandinavia, release Scotland from the United Kingdom and form your own Empire.Play as Prussia and Form The North German Confederation, and then Germany, play as Two Sicilies and form Italy, play as France and become a giant Blob, the choice is yours, for 100 years you are free to achieve your goals, and watch the world change, not even the AI choose the same path each time.Will the Communist Rebels in France take Paris and install their own Government? Will the Anarcho-Liberal anarchists take power in Russia? Will America spread burgers throughout the world? Will the Soviet Union fall to Democratic Germany, will Fascist France continue its rivalry with Communist Britain? Will Australia become a Communist Global power and vie with Democratic New Zealand? Or will the Democratic Rebels in the West stutter the Aussies' Chances? Will the Irish Rebels beat back the British units and Declare independence? Will Liberia colonize all of Africa before the Scramble even starts? Will Texas Annex Mexico? Will the California Republic invade Hawaii? Will the CSA end the Civil war with a Stalemate? Will the CSA come begging to the USA again for Union? Will Poland into Space? Will Bolivia into Coastline? Will Switzerland sit on its bum and watch the world go by? Will China industrialize and defeat the Western industry? Will Russia keep Alaska? I'm not certain, but all of this is possible in Victoria 2.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												As of 30/05/15 I have played much more Victoria 1 than 2 however that will soon change. Personally I love both games in short I loved Victoria 1 as it allowed me to function militarily or economically in huge detail, whereas most games only allowed me to do one of these in the detail I wanted. As in my review for Victoria 1 I would like to point out once again how this game is not for the casual gamer due to the deep and complex systems that you must learn to manage through error to be victorious in militarily, economic or political means. The biggest advantage over Victoria 1 is the diplomacy this is more in depth and allows you to gain power by been wise and commanding of the world, instead of a rudimentary system where only alliances and basic trades are implemented. Most features of this game are easy to grasp at basic levels but to use them to their capacity a few games will have to be played to learn from the mistakes that you will undoubtedly do and suffer from. For most players the combat system in Victoria 2 is less complex than 1 I personally have not noticed much difference, however considering this game is about retaining power and control when it is slipping away from you been simpler is arguably the military commanders doing this. However for those who are to aggressive and don't exploit the other excellent features in the economic and diplomatic fields be warned of infamy. In my Victoria 1 review I talked about the outdated graphics, whilst I still stand about how they are unique and you will get used to them the graphics on Victoria 2 are much better and I do prefer them by no means is this an ugly game. Whilst impressive graphics are not included they do their job and are not key for a strategy game. Another improvement over Victoria 1 is the population control instead of just assigning roles you can also influence what gets built and who wins the elections in a far more complex system which fits the game. The fact you can play as any nation at the starting points allows replayability, but can you maintain your nations status or will you destroy the old powers? Build a new economic or military superpower which will have the old orders living in fear and the nations previously aligned to them at your will instead? Militarist, economist or diplomat? New or old order? The world can be your oyster but can you make it?

content:
Posted: January 30
												   In Victoria II (1836-1936) you manage your country throughout the industrial revolution. The game engine feels dated because it lacks a lot of quality of life improvements and it doesn't look too pretty. Underneath the hood, there is a complex system that keeps track of the population in great complexity, and if there was a Nobel Prize for video games, then this game would've won it. But even if there is a lot of complexity underneath, you don't really have that many options with what you can do. The AI is not that great and is vulnerable to large military stacks. You can't have more than two great powers allied, and while this is a much too "gamey" mechanic for my taste, alongside "crises" that can appear, it can lead to a lot of volatile situations. In the end, the world can be a pretty dangerous and unforeseeable place. If you have a lot of states in your sphere of influence, then your game can transform in a very tedious mini-game to properly maintain and manage them, and of course you lack at least a proper notification system for it. Overall it's a good game, with good mods, which can keep you hooked for a long time, but it really makes you yearn for a Victoria III. Rating: But Mom, you promised me Italy! Recommendation: Are you into grand strategy games even if they look dated? Want to play a Paradox Interactive mega-campaign? http://pixelloot.com

Posted: March 19, 2015
												Victoria II is a fantastic game. I'm a player of strategic games since 1992, there are more than 20 years of experience. I played games like Civilization I, II, III, IV, V, Call to Power, C-Evo, Freeciv, and others. With friends develop a mod for civilization IV over 5 years (Realism Invictus) and say that none of them made me so motivated. It was a great joy to have contact with a really challenging game. Imagine yourself in the following situation: reactionary rebels invaded the capital, conquering it. Deploy retrograde policies, reducing the social advances. The result of this dictatorship were more 80 years this scheme without the right to vote. Feel in the skin become a secondary country like Brazil from 1836 to a superpower. Make allies and engage in a major world war. Want more? Play Victoria II!Victoria II é um jogo fantástico. Sou jogador de jogos de estratégia desde de 1992, são mais de 20 anos de experiência. Joguei jogos como Civilization I, II, III, IV, V, Call to Power, C-Evo, Freeciv. Desenvolvo com amigos um mod para civilization IV a mais de 5 anos (Realism Invictus) e digo que nenhum deles me deixou tão motivado. Foi uma alegria imensa ter contato com um jogo realmente desafiador. Imagine-se na seguinte situação: rebeldes reacionários invadem sua capital, conquistando-a. Implantam políticas retrográdas, diminuindo os avanços sociais. O resultado desta ditadura foram mais 80 anos deste regime sem direito a voto. Sinta na pele tornar um país secundário como o Brasil de 1836 a uma superpotência. Faça aliados e se envolva em uma grande guerra mundial. Quer mais? Jogue Victoria II

												Had it for less than a week and already poured 39 hours into it. It is a seriously good game - well, if you enjoy these sorts of games, that is.50+ hours into it, and I'm still enjoying it (but playing other games now, mind you) and noting that there is a lot of replayability in it, be it through mods or just switching between the various available nations in the game.Want to form a communist state in Europe, or even the United States? Go for it. Want to create fascist states in Norway, Sweden or even Great Britain? Have fun. Or just interested in world conquest and the creation of an industrial super-power? Give it a try.The game has just about everything you need in it. A good game to play alongside Crusader Kings II or EUIV.I'd recommend it any day.

												1100 hours on record says it all, the game is fantastic but you should really use the POP-demand mod for maximum fun. the mod adds more decisions, nations, events, great wars and improved economy / crisis system. Overall you influence the nation but not in a way that wouldnt make sense, like you cant just decide '' I will go communist now and just roll with it, you have the population / upper house etc which all influence your nation.Naturally in terms of military it uses a simple but effective and fun system which is challanging but is easy to get in to, the game has massive replay value with many different nations, paths and formable nations ( like the Danubian Confederation, Germany, Arabia) which require certain conditions to archieve.The game is a massive challange and sometimes the game can turn ugly but if its for a discount i honestly recommend the game if you like crusader kings, Hearts of Iron or other massive RTS games. 9/10

												Victoria 2 is one of my favourite games of all time. It's fun, has a high learning curve and shows huge potential. Some things are lacking and should be improved upon though.+ Great soundtrack+ A lot of countries to choose from. You can even play as Luxemburg...if you want.+ Fun and addicting gameplay.+ supports Mods that offer even more content+ High learning curve with a lot of payoff+ The DLCs are no rip-off like in other Paradox Games.- The crisis system, the political parties and the decisions needs to be worked on- The economy is somewhat broken.- No family tree- Annexing regions cost should be scaled and depend on each region's worth. Right now it isn't. Also, annexing remnant parts of a region should cost less if you already own other parts of it.- Recruiting and maintaining your unit stacks is a chore. This needs to be changed urgently. Make sure to get the DLCs "Heart of Darkness" and "A House Divided".Replay value: highRating: 9/10Recommendation: Yes

												Straight from the best in the Grand Strategy industry, Victoria II puts you on the throne of any nation in the world in 1836 and lets you do whatever the hell you want with the world. No winning, no losing (besides being annexed), no goals besides ones you make yourself. Does have some stupid bits (capitalists are literally as dumb as IRL) but these are minor in the game overall. Endless replayability, great mods, attention to detail, and ability to create the glorious Danube Federation gives this game a 9/10.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Victoria 2 is another RTS with a pause game from the fine folks at Paradox Interactive and set during the height of European colonial and Imperial power. Typically when you hear 'RTS' the first thing that pops into your mind are games like Command&Conquer and other simple 'point, click ,conquer' games where your simple goal is to win the war by any means or casualties necessary. Nothing wrong with that, but if that is the kind of strategy you enjoy you should stay far, far away from the far more realistic perspective that Victoria II offers.Typically Paradox games are never the same (though their somewhat simplistic map and interface might lead some to think they are just the same game in different period), with Crusader Kings series focusing on dynastic ambition, Europa Univeralis on amassing a massive Empire and Hearts of Iron on winning the World Wars. Victoria 2 falls into that golden sweet spot between Europa Universalis and Hearts of Iron where the history is already written. Some things are quite likely to happen no matter what you do: such as the Germanies being united by either Prussia, Austria or Bavaria. Liberalism will also gain strength around the world and the USA will emerge as a Great Power without peer.Other things though? Not quite so certain. You can easily cripple even the largest powerhouse such as the United Kingdom with an illtimed or ill-fought war that leads to hundreds of thousands of your precious Pops dying out; in essence crippling your industry and dooming you to a waiting game where you hope to recussitate your lagging economy. Thankfully the game has a deep, and I mean DEEP economy system which you can spend hours or even days simply trying to manipulate to become an economic powerhouse without peer. Some games are actually simply put games where you try to maximize your economic potential and gain a toehold in the global market and they can be just as fun and rewarding... or even more so than a traditional warfare approach.I could go onto rant about the depth, beauty and awesomness of Victoria II, but I figure I should sum this up somehow:+Incredibly deep and complex.+Lots of replay value.-Unpolished gem.-Graphics can be a turn off for some.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												For the price, this is an excellent game. My dissapointment was that the one great power who's capital is outside Europe, the United States, is not given much chance to influence factors outside of it's own continent. Expansion into the western portion of North America is heavily simplified and doesn't give you the feeling of manifest destiny that I was hoping for. Europe appears to be fine though, so if you're planning on uniting Germany under Prussia, it's probably A-OK and you won't have much trouble (An AI did it in my game). Although it adds tension, making every great power want to expand their influence at every opportunity can lead to scenarios where the tiniest infraction on someone (in my case, developing a reason to declare war on Hawaii as the U.S.) leads to situations such as a Great Britian who decided to ally mexico, declaring war on me. During that conflict, I had to fight a war on two fronts and Jacobin rebels spawned with about four times the army the Confederates fielded during the civil war. There was no hope to win after that.Overall, I wish it focused more on history and less on these strange scenarios that pop up every so often. On the other hand, if you're a fan of alternate history, you'll probably love this game. If the game is on sale, I recommend buying it with the DLC. Thanks for reading my review and have a good time.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												I got into this game after playing the Total War series- I loved Rome 1 and Shogun but was a little disappointed by the other games and so wanted something new. I stumbled across Victoria 2 and as it was on a sale bought it thinking it looked interesting. Best decision ever. Although at first I had no idea what I was doing, after playing all the tutorials and picking a moderately sized country (Belgium- good industry and small so a good starting point, can get frustrating later on in the game because of its tiny military). I spent about 60-70 hours on this first play through and loved every second. The economics are so detailed, and political system is pretty complex and the whole game is very realistic. I then played a second campaign as Prussia, uniting the whole of Germany within 10 years and am now at 1928 as the top country in the world by several thousand points having won 5 Great Wars. My only issue with the game would be that the combat is still a bit of a mystery to me- I mostly just create huge stacks and hope. Otherwise this is an absolutely brilliant game which is well worth buying, especially if you see it on sale

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Yeah it's alright.  Overwealming at first but due to a very intricate economical system that works well.  It's somewhat limited by it's time of the years 1836 to 1936, as a result a lot of the same things happen in every playthrough for the first half of the game, the flip side of the coin is that it has a sense of structure that holds up the sandbox element well.  There are some issues with the AI, most of which have been patched in the downloadable content if you're willing to pay for them.  It can be questionable to have a nationwide population of a few million and become delved into civil war against as many soldiers as your population, massacuring them and have them return unskaved to their factory jobs only to rebell once again.  It has a reasonably simple to understand military system, but in no way dumbed down.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Another guide by Gaius Julius CeasarWell to start it off this game was on my wishlist for a little while, it seemed to be a game that I wanted the total war series to be like. Victoria II however exeeded all of the expectations it had. The game is much more political than the total war series, the conquest is also different from the total war series, as I am still trying to master sending armies over seas! ( that makes playing as Great Britain impossible, shame but once I learn how to Britain here I come! ) You also can conquer ( sorry my English is not my strongest point ) more territory, with each country having around 14 or more provinces and the whole world being right there for the taking you will find yourself drawn into the game and struggling to get out! Another thing is you do not find any settlements to take over, you just move a army into the province and wait, this is different from the total war series yet again.I believe I should also mention that there is no end turn... Every country gets to make their choice of what happens at the same time you do, so if you are expecting a total war end button thing then do not, I was and it took me a while to realize that there is something in the top left corner with a pause button on it, once you click that you can use the + and - signs to change the speed of what happens, and because everything happens together it makes it much harder to plan something, because when you move to attack one army they could move to attack yours! I hope you buy the game and enjoy it as much as what I did.Yours Sincerly Gaius Julius Ceasar

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												Victoria 2 is a next level of depth for a game that I had no idea was possible. Everything from encouraging a certain type of job in some far off tiny colony in Africa to managing your country's economy is possible along with everything in between. This is not just a map simulator, but more of a world simulator. Not appeasing the public's will will bring rebellions and will shift the balance of your government. You can go from having a war-happy nation to one that cuts itself off from the world because your population drastically shifted their vote due to you gaining too much infamy or not passing a policy reform that 2+ million people wanted. This game is for people that love to do nothing but micro-manage on a large scale. The conquering of countries and waging wars is the fun side of this game, but what really creates another level of realism is managing your country like a true president/dictator/king would.

												Where to begin?First off, this game is amazing, it has an in depth view of governmental structure, population management, and economics.All these things combined assist in creating one of the most detailed strategy games of all time.Secondly, mods for this game are brilliant, they help bring new factors into the game.Such as WW2 or even modern day geopolitics,these come with new challenges but they still stay true to the game at heart.Lastly, the alternate history of this game is so pleasing. Whether it be France conquering all of Prussia or the US expanding out across both Americas, it is just a treat.All in all, I'd give this game a solid 10/10.I feel that even if there were tons of bugs, I'd still adore this game's content and experience. Its very well polished and even though it does have some odd moments (walking from Paris to Delhi instead of taking a ship), it is still a fun game to get immersed into, especially if you loooooooooooooove spreadsheets!

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Vic2 was my second exposure to historical strategy sim games.  EUIII was my first try and it does not trip my trigger.  I usually play in north america.  CSA succeeds in splitting off.  When I first got the game, Great Britain would eventually take territory from USA, but updates seem to have changed that behavior.  The aspects of Vicky that I like are:1.  rebel uprisings.  They can make you hustle.  But you can beat them by watching the level of unrest and if necessary mobilizing troops.2. national focus.  What you choose will affect how the game plays out.  Choose to promote immigration and populaton will grow.  Choose a political focus, and you may have fewer rebellions.3. north america-  this is my home and the states are familiar to me, as is the history.  So I like playing in north america.4. anti-imperialism - the game is set up for imperialists, since the era was imperialistic.  But you don't have to play it that way.  The ai is imperialistic, so every one of your neighbors will try to eat your lunch, but you can play them  off against each other via alliances.  And of course you need good border defenses.5.  modding- Big mods are hard but mini-mods are easy.  Just (using the mod folder) change the lua file.  For example, I don't like all the time spent on research, so I changed all research (for all countries) to one day in the lua file. I also cranked up the militancy for captured territories (ha!)  And I changed the end date of the game.6.  policy choices-if you don't pick the reforms with eye on public opinion, you will get into trouble.7. budget- this can be tricky but if you are sensible you can avoid bankruptcy.8. economy- this is more for watching than messing with.  Lots of computing seems to go into the choices made by shadowy capitalists.  But also you need to cancel subsidies now and then or your budget will suffer.I recommend the game.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												If you are looking for a REALISTIC alternate history game, then this is one of the best games out there. The breadth and extant of this game are incomparable. However, that said, there are several words of advice I have:1. To fully enjoy this game, you must have the Pops Of Darkness modifier. This modifier takes a good game and makes it much better.2. The US political system is not very accurate. There should be a seperate system for the US, in the sense of that no political system available accurately represents the United States. Democracy in this game is based upon the British system of non-set elections, multiple parties, etc. The United States has always had set elections and a two-party system. It is hard to play as the United States in the political sense as a result. 3. The game should have been extended in time frame. An earlier start, such as 1776, would be more accurate, or even earlier, possibly as early as British unification. By the time the game commences, the United Kingdom is extremely dominant in the global sphere; countries such as Spain and Sweden are shadows of themselves, the best colonial lands are already taken (in the Americas and southern Africa), and if you are playing as Germany, Italy, or Japan, it is quite difficult to get even a small fraction of British power and influence. An earlier start would leave much colonial land open (particulary in North and South America, as well as Australasia), and some smaller powers (such as the Netherlands or Sweden), would have a fair shot at becoming dominant internationally.4. Immigration seems to need some adjustments, particulary when it comes to Chinese and Japanese migrations. Although China and Japan were not civilized, massive Chinese immigration to the United States began in the 1850's. Even with these countries becoming civilized, there is essentially no migration from non White nations to the Americas. Furthermore, decisions should be written in, to represent the Chinese exclusion acts.5. Some political correctness needs to be written out of the game. In other words, there should be decisions that allow for forcible population transfers. The Jews were often expelled from European countries, and like the Trail of Tears decision in the United States, many other minority groups have been forcibly moved throughout history. This is not a "politically correct" historical fact, but it is a fact.6. On the same note, there should be decisions that allow for freed slaves to be expelled. Historically, Liberia and Sierra Leone were founded for ex-slaves, and Pres. Lincoln of the United States debated in sending freedmen to Belize or Africa. Overall, this is a great game. These developers spent massive hours in research, and it shows. That said, even the best games can use some tweaks, and a project of this scale is no exception.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												This game is one of My favorite games that I have ever played. It is an incredibly complex game to learn. However once you learn how to manage your economy, how to become a great of secondary power, and how to manage your military properly this game just feels right. The way you control your nation just feels right. However this game is far from flawless. Here are some of the problems that I experienced in the game. When I First started this game up it crashed on the loading screen.However I found a solution to this game breaking glitch. First you go to your files. Next go to OS, then program files (x86), next go to steam, then SteamApps, commmon, then go into Victoria 2,( I would suggest making a shortcut)Go into map, then cache, delete all the files in the cache folder but not to folder itself. It is fixed.The aircraft in this game is treated like soldiers which is just stupid, because you cannot fly over enemy territory and cannot destroy enemy structures. Also you cannot fly overseas. You could have at least make them look like actual aircraft.The province occupation system is wierd. How can it take over 100 days to occupy a small province like for example Frankfurt, with over 15k soldiers?There are still some more flaws in this game that I can't remember.However with or without flaws this game is amazing and still has a tonne of potential.If only the developers would recognise the potential that this game has to offer and continue working on it.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												one of the best Paradox games. it covers a period not often shown, and with an accuracy and depth of choice that encourage strategic play. the economic system is extemely difficult to understand, and for most players, is best left to run itself, but if you're feeling confident, a planned economy can be powerful. most of the time, players will try to be good members of the international community but later on when great wars and new technologies become available, an ambitious player has the potential to really go crazy. unlike most paradox games, where everything gets easier over time, your country is always balanced. small countries are harder to play of course, but even well developed great powers require skilled play to do more than a little map painting. not for everyone, but I recommend it without hesitation to anyone willing to invest some time into a more complex grand strategy game.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												This is one of my true favourites when it comes to Paradox games. They're in general similar, but with differences. In EU it's the renaissance era progress towards centralized states, so much will be about land, army and navy, in CK you have your family tree and it's alot about breeding, HoI is more total war than anything else, but this game I consider to be the most complex of them all. It's not just the buildning of an army/navy and eventually air force, but also about infrastructure, industrialization, colonies, and your population. Your population aren't homogenous, not only does it consist of differnt national groups, but there's catholics, protestants and jews, there's clerks, farmers, soldiers and capitalists, and then on top they all have their own political view on things. Now, different choices you make will also alter parameters here, so it will change over time, and also does so according to events and things happening in the world as a whole. Governing a nation will also be alot about channeling these things into forming a nation, or strengthening a existing one. In the end, it usually funnels out into the Great War.So, if you like the time of industrialization,  and if you like complexity, this is the game for you. I most definetly recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 6
												Paradox sale first timers, please be advised that the €12 purchase is an absolute must if you want to enjoy Victoria 2 to its fullest potential. That price will get you one of the finest titles Paradox has ever produced, even without the plethora of excellent mods put out by the community you will be able to find countless hours of enjoyment from this game.The learning curve and the archaïc user interface might scare off people who are entirely new to grand strategy but the beauty of Victoria 2 is that in the 100 years you are given, you are completely free to do whatever you want. Running a country into the ground to help you understand the basics is a downright fun experience if you do it right (See how fast you can get the South to secede! Have the North secede! Who cares, it's the 19th century!) and from there on out you can set your own goals, you can even play with your friends.If you decide to make a purchase worth your while, do stop by /r/paradoxplaza on reddit, the community there partakes in campaign memoires writing sessions (also known as After Action Reports), we would be delighted to hear about your experiences! By Jingo!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Victoria II is a truly unique grand strategy game, one that goes in depth into everything. While some may find the economics system confusing, it can be handled in a timely manner by moving a few sliders around, or in the long run, adjusting every tiny thing as you go along. Wars, while an important part of the game and expanding your nation, are not the main focus of the game, but rather keeping a stabilized country. To go to war is not only to expand your borders, but to expand your economy and influence in a region. Civil wars and revolts may occur if you are not in a stable position, unfortunately caused because of liberals, your lack of assimilation in a region, or the people of your proud nation want changed policies.I would recommend this great grand strategy game to anyone who enjoys a game of its type, be it a fascination with the countries in it, the type of game, or both.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												I think it's time I write my first real review of a steam game--and I'm happy to make it this one.Victoria II has a steep learning curve, but if you open yourself up: it's easy and addicting.The attraction to Victoria II is not its asthetics, it's its offering to let you take on a whole new history.Victoria II plops you into 1836, right before the crowning of Queen Victoria and at the height of the British Empire. The Hapsburg Monarchy still rules the Austrian Empire and Germany is still divided into many small states. The Tsars rule over the Russian Empire that still seeks its greatest extents and America is not even 100 years old.  France emerges from the Napoleonic wars in defeat but a new spring is just around the corner. The Ottoman Empire is the "sick man of Europe" but with the right leadership can embrace the new age with renewed vitality.And even more nations await emergence: Japan, China, and of course the oncoming rush for Africa will change the face of the world.Any nation is playable in Victoria II. Even more can be released or formed. Almost every game is different.War isn't the focus here. Though it is an intriguing aspect. What will draw you in: is the diplomacy.Now that may sound boring but pay in mind the dynamics here. Although the great powers rule and may keep you in-check, playing as one (or better-yet, using them to your advantage to gain power) will keep you thrilled.The Great powers of the time compete to influence other, smaller nations. Intricate webs of alliances and spheres can easily turn a localized conflict into a world war.Crises over disputed territories can cause Great Powers to go at-odds, lobbying other powers to join their side in the tension-packed period where the world can drift into destructive war.Later in the game, these can mean "great wars" were defeat can mean total decimation.In fact, each country is only one war-gone-bad from collapse.Compete to establish puppet states who will obey your every whim.Sphere nations to earn off their industry and almost garantee their support.Colonize the unsettled worlds of Africa, the Pacific, and North America. Keep other nations from doing the same.Also there are different civilization levels. Primitive, Uncivilized, partially civilized, and civilized. Depending on what stage your in impacts your ability to function as a state as your technology will be way behind, you won't be able to build industries, ect. until you "westernize" and join the world as a modern-style nation-state.This alone can be fun as you struggle to survive in the old ways or fight against your own people who resist your attempts to change their very culture.Warfare itself is more fleshed-out than initially realized. Your armies' ability to do recconassaince, perform sieges, and fight in battle is dependent upon their specilized unit makeup and perhaps too-often ignored: their generals.An army of 80,000 draftees can be thrawted by a smaller, diverse professional army and an excellently-chosen general who can earn fame by winning battles which will in-turn provide greater bonuses.Naval power is a MUST to establish yourself as a colonial power. Blockades can WRECK your trade. And just as with armies: diversity and excellent Admirals can win you the day.Trade itself can be largely ignored and should be automated unless you feel otherwise inclined.Politics within your own country can grab your attention.The availible government types are:DemocracyHM's GovernmentPrussian ConstitutionalismAbsolute MonarchyProletarian DictatorshipFascist DictatorshipBorgeouseis DictatorshipPresidential Dictatorship.To better understand this, the political party in power decides your trade policy, your tax policy, your military spending, how you treat minorities, ability to intervene/control factories and industry, and your upper house (legislative body) will decide what reforms you can impliment.Democracies are governments where the party in power is elected and they guide policy until the next election.HM's Government are the same but you have the ability to change the government in power (though reforms will require the appropriate members in said upper house). Prussian Constitutionalism is this wierd grey-area between Absolute Monarchies and Democracies though usually have elections.Absolute Monarchies have no elections (which by the way are totally annoying and only nudge public opinion especially in large countries) and can choose the ruling party.Then come the dictatorships which are usually single-party.THE BEST PART IS YOU GET DIFFERENT FLAGS DEPENDING ON YOUR GOVERNMENTSOMETIMES DIFFERENT NAMES.An example is Mexico who, if they have a monarch, will change to the Empire of Mexico.The United Kingdom will change to Great Britain if a democracy or the People's Commonwealth if a proletarian dictatorship,These will also cause flag changes.Rebels will lobby for reform changes or even radical government change. Sometimes you might want them to win. There's nothing wrong with letting the generals plot a dictator's downfall.Now finally mods which really can give a lot of replayability to this game.Mods are relatively easy to get though are not taken from the steam workshop but from websites like Moddb.These mods have infinite potential offering different timelines, scenerios, new nations, new flags, new alternate timelines.Some even add events to the more minor nations to make them more dynamic to play. OHONE MORE THINGMultiplayer IS possible, don't worry. And trust me, it's awesome with friends.You can coordinate to carve up continents for your empires.You can plot against each-other. A great game is Austria and Prussia competing for dominance.Here's how we do it:Download Hamachi which will allow you to create a network your friends can connect to.They will use the Hamachi-provided IP address the host of the network has to connect to your game.It's advised to put the game to save often. We do half-years.Make sure you verify the integrity of your game cache every time you play together. And close out of the game entirely if someone crashes and do so again just to be sure.You MUST have the same version to operate.If you want to load saves, the host (and only the host) needs to disable their firewalls.another thing: the Host should host the hamachi network AND the multiplayer game.We haven't tried mods yet.To conclude this review, make sure you invest into this game (and hope someday for another Paradox game that picks up where this one leaves off--1939 or somewhere around that era). It may seem overwhelming at first, but attack and google around if you're lost. Usually you can find a forum post where they have your question or you can start your own.Find friends to join the game with you.Take pictures. f12.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												I think it's time I write my first real review of a steam game--and I'm happy to make it this one.Victoria II has a steep learning curve, but if you open yourself up: it's easy and addicting.The attraction to Victoria II is not its asthetics, it's its offering to let you take on a whole new history.Victoria II plops you into 1836, right before the crowning of Queen Victoria and at the height of the British Empire. The Hapsburg Monarchy still rules the Austrian Empire and Germany is still divided into many small states. The Tsars rule over the Russian Empire that still seeks its greatest extents and America is not even 100 years old.  France emerges from the Napoleonic wars in defeat but a new spring is just around the corner. The Ottoman Empire is the "sick man of Europe" but with the right leadership can embrace the new age with renewed vitality.And even more nations await emergence: Japan, China, and of course the oncoming rush for Africa will change the face of the world.Any nation is playable in Victoria II. Even more can be released or formed. Almost every game is different.War isn't the focus here. Though it is an intriguing aspect. What will draw you in: is the diplomacy.Now that may sound boring but pay in mind the dynamics here. Although the great powers rule and may keep you in-check, playing as one (or better-yet, using them to your advantage to gain power) will keep you thrilled.The Great powers of the time compete to influence other, smaller nations. Intricate webs of alliances and spheres can easily turn a localized conflict into a world war.Crises over disputed territories can cause Great Powers to go at-odds, lobbying other powers to join their side in the tension-packed period where the world can drift into destructive war.Later in the game, these can mean "great wars" were defeat can mean total decimation.In fact, each country is only one war-gone-bad from collapse.Compete to establish puppet states who will obey your every whim.Sphere nations to earn off their industry and almost garantee their support.Colonize the unsettled worlds of Africa, the Pacific, and North America. Keep other nations from doing the same.Also there are different civilization levels. Primitive, Uncivilized, partially civilized, and civilized. Depending on what stage your in impacts your ability to function as a state as your technology will be way behind, you won't be able to build industries, ect. until you "westernize" and join the world as a modern-style nation-state.This alone can be fun as you struggle to survive in the old ways or fight against your own people who resist your attempts to change their very culture.Warfare itself is more fleshed-out than initially realized. Your armies' ability to do recconassaince, perform sieges, and fight in battle is dependent upon their specilized unit makeup and perhaps too-often ignored: their generals.An army of 80,000 draftees can be thrawted by a smaller, diverse professional army and an excellently-chosen general who can earn fame by winning battles which will in-turn provide greater bonuses.Naval power is a MUST to establish yourself as a colonial power. Blockades can WRECK your trade. And just as with armies: diversity and excellent Admirals can win you the day.Trade itself can be largely ignored and should be automated unless you feel otherwise inclined.Politics within your own country can grab your attention.The availible government types are:DemocracyHM's GovernmentPrussian ConstitutionalismAbsolute MonarchyProletarian DictatorshipFascist DictatorshipBorgeouseis DictatorshipPresidential Dictatorship.To better understand this, the political party in power decides your trade policy, your tax policy, your military spending, how you treat minorities, ability to intervene/control factories and industry, and your upper house (legislative body) will decide what reforms you can impliment.Democracies are governments where the party in power is elected and they guide policy until the next election.HM's Government are the same but you have the ability to change the government in power (though reforms will require the appropriate members in said upper house). Prussian Constitutionalism is this wierd grey-area between Absolute Monarchies and Democracies though usually have elections.Absolute Monarchies have no elections (which by the way are totally annoying and only nudge public opinion especially in large countries) and can choose the ruling party.Then come the dictatorships which are usually single-party.THE BEST PART IS YOU GET DIFFERENT FLAGS DEPENDING ON YOUR GOVERNMENTSOMETIMES DIFFERENT NAMES.An example is Mexico who, if they have a monarch, will change to the Empire of Mexico.The United Kingdom will change to Great Britain if a democracy or the People's Commonwealth if a proletarian dictatorship,These will also cause flag changes.Rebels will lobby for reform changes or even radical government change. Sometimes you might want them to win. There's nothing wrong with letting the generals plot a dictator's downfall.Now finally mods which really can give a lot of replayability to this game.Mods are relatively easy to get though are not taken from the steam workshop but from websites like Moddb.These mods have infinite potential offering different timelines, scenerios, new nations, new flags, new alternate timelines.Some even add events to the more minor nations to make them more dynamic to play. OHONE MORE THINGMultiplayer IS possible, don't worry. And trust me, it's awesome with friends.You can coordinate to carve up continents for your empires.You can plot against each-other. number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Paradox Interactive must be the masters of Strategy games. This is one of their finest. Victoria II is set in the Victorian Era in the 19th and early 20th century. From 1836 to 1936, you have 100 years to lead a nation to triumph. There are no official goals in the game. You make the goals. But the de-facto prospect is making a country into an economic or military superpower. Some nations like Great Britain are already big at the start, but playing a small nation like Greece can give you the opportunity to give it a time it never saw. That's right. You're not playing history. You're re-writing it. Every little thing you do in the game can have big, unintentional outcomes. Doing something in North America might somehow cause a war in Europe. You never know.This is just how fun Victoria II is for history buffs. You can play unlikely countries and turn them into a colonial superpowers. I played Ireland and gave it African colonies. I claimed the island of Hawaii for Mexico, preventing the USA from annexing it in actual history. I played the Confederate States of America and fought hard for it's independence and giving it colonies around the world. There is just so much you can do. So many opportunities.But while that sounds like a lot of fun, you're going to have to work hard to achieve your goals. This game has a huge learning curve. In fact, I was almost turned off by the game when playing it for the first time because of how complex it was. But learning is the fun part. I didn't spend a lot of time with the tutorial. I just played around and learned as played. Right now, I know how this game works. But I'm still learning. As I said before, you have to work hard. There's a lot of things to do when managing a country. Here are those things.- You have to manage taxes and government spending. Some countries might have to rely on heavy taxing on the poor, middle and rich if the government lacks a lot of money in their bank. You might also have to cut down on military and infastructure spending to rake in cash. If you are in serious decline of money, you can borrow funds from the bank. But you will have to repay those debts. Some nations have the population and profits to not worry about funding. But other small nations will.-Economy management. You might have to open factories to gain profits. Depending on your country's economic policy. You can open factories or let the AI capitalists do them for you. These factories needs craftsmen and whatever resources the factories need. And let's talk about that next.-Resources. This is the fun part. Let's face it. Some nations don't have everything they need. A small country like Texas (which lacks a big population and resources) might have to go to war and conquer weaker nations to prosper. Colonies help boost the resources and pops you need. -War. It's not the primary focus of the game, but it's a whole lot of fun. War is not the goal. War helps your goals. As mentioned before, you might need to start a war to conquer a nation/colony for more resources. Or you might go to war to establish a puppet-state which acts like a permanent alliance. Whatever suits your agenda, War can help you.-Diplomacy. Okay, it's not really the intriguing part but politics and international relations is what makes things more interesting in Vic 2. If you want to survive, you might need to make a few friends when making more enemies.- Technological advancement. You got a century to run a country and while years go by, new technologies will be available for you to develop. This is how a country will improve and become stronger. Military, Naval, Commerce, Culture and Industry are the 5 tech trees you can develop on the way. Culture, industry and Commerce might be important for nations that are just sitting around, but warmongers might like Military and Naval much more better. All 5 of the trees are important however, so don't try and pick the military ones only.-Politics. Oh man, sometimes the hardest part of running the nation is how to deal with your citizens. If you're a democracy, people are gonna have vote for their favorite political party. And each political party that could be in power, will affect your nation. Hell, if you're population manages to vote the Communist Party in, you might accidently have caused your country to be a dictatorship. If you're not managing your country well, rebellions can happen and if you can't fight off the rebellions with your military, you might be running a new government soon. You can also make political and social reforms like voting policies or whether or not the minimum wage should be lower.-Colonization. This is the best part of Victoria II. There are several uncolonized parts of the world. Not that they lack populations but that there are no established nations there. Australia & New Zealand are mostly uncolonized with the exception of a few provinces. But most likely, Britain will do inevitably colonize them. North America will be the only continent to be fully colonized quickly. There are unclaimed land that the United States, Mexico or Britain will grab before the 1850's. But the glory of colonization occurs in Africa. Most of the continent is unclaimed. There's only a few nations and small colonial settlements that exist. -Modernization. Europe, in this time period has the technology that is top of the line. So most of the world is somewhat behind compared to Europe. So if you're playing a country in Africa or Asia, you will want to spend some time modernizing. Japan is the pretty much the only country in the game that modernizes so quickly. But not only that, you get to turn Japan into a colonial superpower faster than any other country that hasn't westernized. While I did not mention everything, there is just so much you can do. Key historical events like the American Civil War can occur when the time is ready. You can also install mods that improve the gameplay experience. The New Nations Mod adds countries that the developers should have added before. I definitely recommend Victoria II for anyone who is into strategy games and history in general. 10/10

												There are few games set in the 1800s, but this one does it well. You take control of any country - from Great Britain to Ethiopia - for one hundred years, starting in 1836 and spanning the American Civil War and Franco-Prussian War, as well as many other wars. For each country, there are many, many options - in fact, the only "quest" that the game gives you is to survive until 1936. The main reason why someone would not like this game is if they need more guidance, but personally I like it, and most grand strategy players will too.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Do you like spreadsheets? What about the endless waiting and worrying over external threats that comes from the futility of contemplating one's existance as a less developed country? In all seriousness, Victoria II is a great game, and stands as one of the most solid Paradox developed games. If you are just getting into the Grand Strategy genre after playing Crusader Kings II or Europa Universalis IV, then some features may be intimidating at first. There is micromanaging present in both of those games, but probably not to the extent that you are likely to experience when playing Vicky. Like all Paradox games there is a pretty steep learning curve, but this should not discourage you as there are loads of helpful tutorials online.You will almost surely start the game try to learn the game as a fairly small nation and end up getting crushed by some event that will seem quite obvious down the line. Try Brazil if you are just starting out. They are a fairly easy nation for learning the base mechanics (using some gamey tactics to take easy uncivilized nations in Africa), but offer a nice challenge in the late game as one usually ends up competing for regional supremacy with the USA.If you're still not convinced, here are some cool things that I have seen during some of my playthroughs:Japan won a war against the Ottomon Empire, and ended up controlling the Hejaz including the holy cities of Mecca and Medina.USA POPs revolted and left the USA controlling only the western portion of the country. The Confederates controlled the South, while the Free States of America controlled the north and had replaced the USA as the continental Great Power.Poland was released in a Great War and promptly proceeded to take up boundaries almost exactly proportional to the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.PROS:1. Maps are nice to look at.2. The unstoppable historical events (think the Mongol invasions of CK2, to a lesser extent) add a structure to the madness that is a Grand Strategy game.3. It is fun to take historically insignificant entities and create a narrative that establishes them as being a dominant power.CONS:1. State control of the means of production ends up feeling like a spreadsheet simulator.2. Game slows down considerably in later years and is especially slow on a lot of laptops.3. You will probably 100x more games than you actually finish

												Best Paradox game ever made.Combine the following games: Democracy, CK2 and Hearts of Iron 3.I used to be a Hearts of Iron 3 addict, and still go back to it a bit, from time to time, when the urge strikes me to conquer the world as Germany or turn everybody into a slave as USSR.But this... Fine, recruit your soldiers.... but will that leave enough to work your factories?Meanwhile you must juggle internal politics (this is one of the few games that gets this right) balancing between need for reform (if any) and people pushing back against it.And of course there are the nations around you, just waiting for that one slip to destroy you.You can lose a war, but losing your national rank in this game hurts a lot more, as great powers, and even secondary powers have many advantages over nations with less worldwide respect.This game is the pinnacle of the Paradox studios.This game is the pinnacle of strategy.This is on par with Distant Worlds, if not better.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												The most interesting of all the Paradox Interactive games. This game does not require you to be a war-monger. This game does not require you to micromanage silly family members. Rather, this game lets you have an extreme challenge by simply maintaining your nation and ideology through some incredible changes in technology and politics. You can also wage a lot of wars without ever expanding your own territory - instead, you simply seek to liberate countries and maintain a democratic, fascist, monarchist, or socialist world order. Even if all you want to do is build up your own little country and develop lots of heavy industry, while maintaining neutrality in the various Great Wars that start happening, that is still challenging and fun.

												To keep the review short, this game will challenge you.In order to enjoy it, as I do, you either need to be a large history fan of the era (1830's to 1910's) or a great fan of grand strategy games, Paradox games in particular.Victoria II is not held as highly rated as EU or CK2 and I can see why as it seems a lot more limiting. HOWEVER saying that it (just as with all paradox games I have played) is a stunningly well made and authentic title and has improved hugely from the first Victoria game. It can be complex as it is highly political but you soon learn to just build a ton of factories and help the capitalists and aristocrats if you want to succeed.A political grand strategy game not a military one. Possibly the best of its kind. Fantastic game highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Oh God, I can't believe that I haven't reviewed this game yet.As I write this, I have 437.3 hrs on record--making this the most played game in my library.-----Victoria II is a game that starts in 1836 and ends in 1936. So 100 years of gameplay. This is one of Paradox's faster paced games, as years can go by very quickly depending on the speed and how you manage that time. In my case, I only play as challenging nations like: Texas, Hawaii, Bali, Nejd, Ionian Islands, Mecklenburg, and Cuba. I find joy in trying to turn a small nation into a successful empire. This usually takes many years to do, however.- Population: The main difference I can list right off the bat, compared to other Paradox titles, is that this game focuses on your population. Your population is comprised of: Farmers, labourers, craftsmen, soldiers, officers, clerks, slaves, and other professions. Naturally, if you want armies, you need soldiers. If you want to become rich, you must employ more workers into your factories, and more labourers into the fields. It's very important to keep your population content with your government, or they may revolt. Many may find revolts tedious and annoying, but I for one believe that revolts are one of the most crucial parts to the game. And I will explain why momentarily.- Politics: While a game like Hearts of Iron III has politics, there isn't much depth to it. You really have little control over what political party rises in Hearts of Iron III. In Victoria 2, your population plays a major role in what political party is elected (assuming that they are allowed to vote!) This game contains 7 different political factions: Liberals, conservatives, anarcho-liberals, reactionaries, socialists, communists, and fascists. Of the 7, I always go socialist--as I am very familiar with this system. Along with the political parties, you can combine this with different types of governments. There are monarchies, democracies, dictatorships (and proletarian dictatorships for the communists.) The best part about government changes, is that the flag of a nation will change as well. For example; if Germany turned into a proletarian dictatorship, they would receive the flag of the DDR. While if they turned into a fascist dictatorship, they acquire the flag of the Third Reich (Kind of...) I love the political aspect of this game, and it is likely the one reason I constantly play this game.- Revolts: As I said, these are usually annoying to you in two ways. 1. They may be attacking your country. 2. They may be attacking a puppet/ally, and thus will tear your ties with that nation if overthrown. Now, on the other hand, rebels are truly what makes the game interesting. The Russians are defeated BADLY in a war, and communist rebels rise. They overthrow the Russian Empire and form the Soviet Union. If you ask me, that's pretty damn interesting! After 80 years of seeing the same old Russian Empire, it's nice seeing them throw out the red color and put on the classic hammer and sickle. How about Scottish rebels? Is it not interesting to see Scotland gain independence from the United Kingdom through violent means? There's both pros and cons to rebels. I personally have NO PROBLEM with rebels, ever. I just choose the socialist party loyalty national focus on my nation, let my nation turn more red, and I seem to be in good hands. Otherwise, if the rebels want to fight, I will go Rocky IV on them. So in other words... I love rebels.- The scramble for Africa: This is such a fun part of the game, but I feel that it mainly improved with the addition of the Heart of Darkness DLC. Throughout your game, you will notice that Africa is a mere wasteland of uncolonized land. There is generally nothing interesting that surrounds Africa until the 1870s, when the doors are unlocked and all great and secondary powers are given the green light to begin colonization. It's nothing short of a big race. Everyone wants to get their hands on the most land, and if you plan things out accordingly (like perhaps annexing Liberia before 1870) you can form a massive African empire. What you choose to do with your newly acquired African land is up to you. Use it for its resources, or release it all into one giant satellite nation. Overall, this is always an exciting event of any campaign.- Technological advancements: In 1870, everyone but the primitive nations essentially start off with the option to build infantry or cavalry, and that's about it. As for navy, you can build anything as simple as a clipper transport or frigate. As time goes on, however, and you research more, you will acquire much more advanced types of infantry and warships. I am personally a big fan of the tanks that are available in the early 20th century. More than tanks, however, I love the battleships. Nothing is more satisfying than having a battleship and spotting an enemy fleet of mere commerce raiders. It's simply too funny of a battle. Unfortunately, technology is not my favorite aspect of this game. I much prefer Hearts of Iron's system and I really wish they had implemented something similar in this game. While Victoria II has a wide variety of technology branches, I simply wish the decisions I make for research was as dynamic as it was in Hearts of Iron. I'm crossing my fingers that next time around, Victoria III (Not announced YET) will give you the option to completely focus on a specific part of the game. Considering I'm pro-navy, I would love if I could continue to improve the strengths of my battleships.In conclusion, I love this game so much. Whenever I look at all of the other grand strategy games on Steam, I contemplate, and I cry. I leap into bed and soak my pillow with tears, understanding that there will never be another day where such a worthy game will hit the stores. ...but I'm just kidding. I love Europa Universalis IV a lot too.This game is currently 75% off until September 8. A fair piece of warning, though. This review was written through the eyes of someone with both A House Divided and Heart of Darkness. While the vanilla game is $5, I highly recommend just grabbing the other two DLC to ensure that you feel you made a satisfying purchase.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Victoria II is the most interesting and addicting grand strategy game that I've ever played hands down. It covers every aspect of the era. Some of those aspects including Industrialization, New Imperialism. Nationalism and the beginning of modern day revolutionist ideas and tactics. When I play Victoria II I feel a bond with the nation I'm playing. I almost develop a temporary sense of nationalism, wanting to further my nation to sitting in the #1 great power spot that it deserves to be in. If a grand strategy game can be so in depth that it makes me feel like I'm actually in the leader's position then the devolopers made this game right. This game perfectly represents the time period and also has educational value. When I played my first run as Prussia using the Historical Project Mod (I would highly recommend this mod. It completely revamps the game to more accurately represent the time period and it also improves many of the statistics and balances the game better.) I often found myself looking into the nation's history and many key decisions the leaders made to form the German Empire. Currently as I'm writing this review I have 536 hours in Victoria II and I only plan to see that number go higher as I continue to play this amazing game.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												The first nation I chose to play as was Russia, which proved to be a terrible choice for obvious reasons. Then I decided to go with a smaller but not highly vulnerable underdog nation to ease my learning curve, and went with Japan. After numerous decades and a dozen or so hours of playtime, not only had I civilized and modernized all of Japan and brought forth a new era of industrial supremacy, but I skyrocketed the nation to the rank of a Great Power. By the 1880's, after multiple successful wars with Russia, Korea, China, and several other countries, Japan nearly tripled in size and had become the 5th greatest nation in the world, right behind Russia. At first I was overcome by the sheer joy of success, as Japan was ranked third in industrial power and was one of the most prestigious nations in the world. Then as my economy began to slow down, my income was turning negative for the first time in over a decade as factories closed and unemployment jumped. I began to raise taxes, cut my military and navy, and then I began to raise doubts about my countries future. Unfortunately, my doubts were realized. As the century turned and the 1900's began, my economy neared depression-level and the national debt was adding up, growing political divisions were threatening the countries stability, and new factions were rising up demanding things like workers rights and calling for a liberal government. The tension came to a boiling point in Pyongyang, where nearly twenty thousand Korean rebels rose up in arms against Japanese rule and were completely annihilated before they could even take two steps forward. At what seemed like the worst time, I was plunged into a war between Germany and Russia, as Germany was the #1 world super power and was my closest ally. Actually, Germany was one of very few countries willing to ally with me as my infamy was a little too high from the Japanese conquests in Korea, China, and Russia. More great powers suddenly joined the war, and it became known as the Great War. My forces were diminished from the get-go, and my allies were too busy fighting their own battles. Before long I was utterly decimated by an invasion force of Russian and French forces and rage quit. I still haven't turned the tide, but nonetheless I rate this game 10/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												 Victoria 2, yet another Grand Strategy Game produced by Paradox Interactive, however unlike Hearts of Iron taking you through the second world war, Victoria 2 takes you through the Victorian era, a period of colonization, nationalism, industrialization, and westernization. You play literally as any country from 1836, from the United States of Central America to the Free City of Kraków, and guide it through the Industrial era and the Victorian era.  Forge your destiny as you guide your nation through 100 years of industrialization, war, and colonization, vie for Great Power status and sign Alliances that at a split second, could be aimed at you, survive anarcho-liberal uprisings and anti-western partisans as you try to westernize as Japan. Along with nations that already exist, there are some that are relasable or formable; defeat the Russian Empire as Sweden and form Scandinavia, release Scotland from the United Kingdom and form your own Empire.  Play as Prussia and Form The North German Confederation, and then Germany, play as Two Sicilies and form Italy, play as France and become a giant blob, the choice is yours, for 100 years you are free to achieve your goals, and watch the world change, not even the AI choose the same path each time.    Will the Communist Rebels in France take Paris and install their own government? Will the Anarcho-Liberal anarchists take power in Russia? Will America spread burgers throughout the world? Will the Soviet Union fall to Democratic Germany, will Fascist France continue its rivalry with Communist Britain? Will Australia become a Communist Global power and vie with Democratic New Zealand? Or will the Democratic Rebels in the West stutter the Aussies' Chances? Will the Irish Rebels beat back the British units and declare independence? Will Liberia colonize all of Africa before the scramble even starts? Will Texas annex Mexico? Will the California Republic invade Hawaii? Will the CSA end the Civil war with a Stalemate? Will the CSA come begging to the USA again for Union? Will Poland into space? Will Bolivia into Coastline? Will Switzerland sit on its bum and watch the world go by? Will China industrialize and defeat the Western industry? Will Russia keep Alaska? Will Jews elect a facist party in Israel? I'm not certain, but all of this is possible in Victoria 2.  Pro's:  +Balanced combat, as well as a nice amount of units (not too many, not too little) and provide nice costumization of forces +Great powers and secondary powers make the game feel more real + Neat political system (upperhouse, elections and reforms) + Factory system + Attention to detail: Each country has its own flags for Monarchy, Republic, Fascist and Communist. And most countries have flavour events. + You can change history  Con´s: - Steep learning curve   Overall rating: 14/15 (Must own for history nerds and strategy gamers)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15
												Any game from Paradox should be seen as an investment; initially they take time to come to grips with but once you have a handle on them, nothing quite scratches that strategy itch. You also get plenty of DLC, while many feel this is nickle and diming - which all too often it is - with Paradox it is to help support the games as they continue to provide updates and keep their games alive far longer than most other game studios. Word to the wise, Steam sales are your friend here, as often Paradox will sell older DLC for around 75% off in larger sales. Also, they fully support the modding community which adds so much value and extra enjoyment. Choose any country and forge it into an Empire that stands first among the Great Powers. I feel Paradox hadn't quite hit their stride here and there are some quirks that don't feel so smooth here. However, the game is vastly enjoyable and eminently time-consuming. If you feel a little at sea, I would recommend finding Let's Plays on YouTube to show you what you might be having difficulty with. I learned the intricacies of Victoria 2 from Shenryyr2, myself. Thanks! Choose your nation, pursue technologies, set your influences, encourage your nation through focuses, and build both armies and navies to police,  expand your Empire to become a Great Power. Take decisions that add flavour to your gameplay.8/10 - would pursue world domination again.
