content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												Victoria II (and its expansion packs) is one of my all-time favorite games. The depth of the game is extraordinary; you can choose to follow a nation's path through history or change it to your liking. The diplomacy, economics, and warfare in the game feel very realistic, especially as the game progresses into the modern era. The learning curve is steep but the process is quite entertaining. A House Divided and Heart of Darkness offer so many improvements to the game, such as the international crisis system and the ability to begin the campaign at the outbreak of the American Civil War. In summary, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys grand strategy games or just have an interest in history (or changing it).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I really hated this game and Europa Universalis when I first got them.  I wanted to jump in, murder all of the nonbelievers and create the world under my iron fist.  This is not that type of game.  Even though Civ and Total War pretend they've made improvements in diplomacy, they still really only come down to killing everyone else.You will not jump into this game and eradicate the lesser countries.  What you can do... is subjugate them under your nation, push your influence, and try and form the nations of Italy, Germany, etc... out of the smaller city states.  Or if your citizens live in a state owned by another nation (such as Greece and the Aegis Islands being owned by the Ottomans), you can through some sneakery diplomacy take them with no bloodshed, or even get the major world powers to do the dirty work for you if you need some early weak undeveloped nations to colonize but lack the resources to mobilize yourself.There's a definite learning curve, but luckily there's Youtube to show you what the heck you're doing.Now that I've given it a second chance and know better what to expect from it, I definitely see what everyone meant about this being the 'big boy game' that you move to when you grow up from Civ (not that I dislike Civ at all).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												After getting this game heavily discounted, I can safely say that it has some of the best value of all the titles found on Steam. You've got tons of nations to choose from, and many play quite differently. Whether you want to expand mercilessly as Prussia, further your empire as the UK, dominate your neighbours as Punjab, or fight to restore Romania, it's up to you. Know that if you want to play a minor, especially an uncivilized nation, that this game is not kind, so be prepared to fight way harder.Anyways, the game is simple to manage, but frustratingly hard to grasp. The tutorial doesn't help. AI management is bad, especially when it comes to consolidating troops, and the game isn't one for those who expect even a loose adherence to history.Beyond that, this game really is terrific, and worthy of a purchase, arguably at full price (Though the expansions seem to be a must). With all that said, there's nothing more satisfying after a century of growth then to see your country as one of the great powers, or even supplanting the UK as number one.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												Victoria II is a grand strategy game from Paradox Interactive, the same company that created Europa Universalis, Crusader Kings, and Hearts of Iron. The game is easy to learn to play, but challenging to master. It features very complex inner-workings that can take a very long time to fully understand, but players willing to tackle the challnges this game brings will be entertained for hundreds of hours.In a nutshell, Victoria II gives the player command of any country on earth in the century from 1836 to 1936. It is a game based on history, but it is not an historical simulation. Expect weird things to occur, like a communist revolution in Texas, a globe-spanning Greek Empire, or a fascist Brunei launching devastating wars of conquest in every continent.The player's role in the game is to ensure their country's success or dominance. Like other Paradox games, you cannot "win" or "lose". There are no standardized goals, like "Conquer 50 provinces" or "Destroy Such-And-Such". Rather, you  do whatever you want to see your country and its population thrive (or collapse into total anarchy and civil war, if that's your thing). You can use any number of tools to see your country grow, from cajoling other states into joining your "sphere of influence", to forcing them in at the tip of your sword; from encouraging immigration to your lands, to conquering more populated lands; from building titanic industrial machines, to dispersing protesting strikers dragging down your titanic industrial machine. Warfare forms the core of the game, with economic and political concerns filling in the peacetime. You'll often find yourself invading other territories to secure access to an important resource your factories need, otherwise those factories will go out of business and uppity, hungry workers will insist on throwing your Absolutely-Monarchical♥♥♥♥♥out on the street to watch in the cold while they establish a Dictatorship of the Proletariat.The game is intricate and difficult to master, but the online community will help you overcome most of the impediments. There is also still something of a modding community, impressive after 4 years. The existing mods are quite fun to play, greatly enhancing aspects of the game or setting it in different eras. All in all, 9/10.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Honestly, I don't know what to write about Victoria II. I raised an island of polar bears to be a (temporary) world power, only to be the 13th power by the end. ("Spoiler tags on an old, grand strategy game? Why would that be?") I've brought Austria up to be a domineering military power. I fought against the Union in the Civil War and lost miserably. I've done so many things, yet there's so much more that I can do. To be straightforward, I am by no means recommending this game for everyone. You have to want to play this sort of game. It's slow, but engrossing. It's difficult, but rewarding. It's boring at times, but then Russia decides it wants half of your country and suddenly you're struggling to build an army, then France decides they want the other half.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												I love this game, I have spent hours on it.In case you are wondering how much, I have played it since it was put on shelf's on one of my favorite stores.Well anyways, my game was a "non-steam" game, so there is no evidence to as how long as I played that version.Though I will say it's more addicting than candy-crush, every nation can be player controlled, and each one of them is unique.It's an inversive game that will keep you hooked, with battle planning, global affairs, and crisises pulling countries into World Wars. Ranging from 1836 to when the world was still recovering from the likes of Napoleon to 1936 just shy of World War 2.With over 100 years, you can set the speed for which your country takes.With Diplomacy and many other things to look after, you'll be kept concentrated on the game. Don't worry, you do not need to micro-manage, the game does that for you, but if you want full control, it's all there.Then there is colonization.America and Mexico compete for land, while Britain colonizes Canada.But you can change this.You choose the alternate course of history, and you can decide who colonizes what.The riches of Africa beckon, a Russian or even Austrian Africa is possible.You guide your country to place itself onto it's rightful place at the top.This is an excellent game, and I recommend it to people who like playing games where you must control a nation.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												After around 160 hours of straight playing, Victoria 2 has been my favourite grand strategy game, I love it more than CK2, HOI3 and EU3. It's been very enjoyable, it has a lot of hidden mechanics, while not being as confusing as HOI3, or as bare bones as CK2. The game has a massive choice of countries, most of which you will be able to succeed with. Whether you are playing Japan or Bavaria, if you're good enough you will be able to play it. The game does have a few lag spikes, but that may just be the five year old or so computer I play it on.                                                                                                      The game has some glitches which can be annoying, but not a lot of them are game breaking. One rather annoying thing is the fact that once you install the expansion, everything is a bit less crazy. I play Paradox games for alternate history,  not to see a bunch of AI gobble up helpless Asiaa Minorites.Still, after that, the game is still absolutely fantastic, and if you are a fan of Paradox Strategy games, you should already own this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												Victoria II, a game which introduced me to Grand Strategy. (This review is abit long hue hue)The game starts off at the peak of the industrial revolution. The world is pushed into this great leap that no one has ever seen before. Smoke rises from the newly built factories. Railroad tracks can be seen in almost every part of the globe, connecting city after city. Warfare has now changed into a more deadlier way. The old wooden ships are now replaced by steam-propelled warships protected by iron or steel plates. It is the early 19th century, and thus a new age is born.Victoria II is a game for those who love grand strategy games and (most importantly) history. This game will blow your mind because of the depth of gameplay that the dev's put into this game. Diplomacy, History, Politics, Warfare, Technology, and even Economy can be seen in this game. Every player has his/her own style of play. You can play as Great Britain and just colonize every part of the world that is not colonized yet. You can be Prussia and unite all the german people into one banner. You can be Denmark and try to make Scandinavia for yourself. You can be any nation you want in this game's time period. This is one of those games that makes you think hard on what to do next. Maybe rise the taxes? Make war to all your neighbors? Take on the Great Powers of the World and try to make them step down from their outstanding greatness? Forge an empire which will humiliate the United Kingdom? Make the richest nation of the world? Isolate yourself from wars or be neutral, like Switzerland? Maintain a monarchy that controls the whole country? It is up to you on how you play your country in Victoria II.Im giving this game a 9/10. Game is amazing but there are times that the AI is just a ♥♥♥♥♥.Grab this game now or in a steam sale. I suggest you get the complete version of the game because its complete and has the awesome uniforms that germany used before and during the years of World War One (which I personally love).

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Single best game I have on Steam. For anyone who enjoys PDS games (like EU, or CK) Victoria 2 is a must have. Some PDS games focus on warfare, like HoI, and because of that many of the non-warfare options can feel like tacked on complications to make war harder. Victoria 2 takes the opposite approach. You can play an entire game without fighting a single battle and yet still have a full and rich experience. If you are looking for something more than a war game, you've found it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Imagine a beautiful piece of music that's recorded on a potato, or a brilliant screenplay with a cast of entirely autistic people. That's what VicII is like -  an incredibly original, balanced and fun game that's just so, so deeply flawed. Don't get me wrong, it's my favourite paradox game (or possibly my favourite game altogether) - there are no other games with this level of depth that just work so well. When everything goes right in VicII - you've made it to the 20th century, you're a great power and you're having an arms race preparing for a great war - it feels completely perfect.I can't think of another game where the actual *gameplay* changes naturally over time. When machine guns, trench warfare and indirect fire artillery have been developed by about 1890, there's no popup saying "Wars are fought statically now!". It just happens to be that to win a war after that point, you have to stop massing your troops into large armies and start lining them along your borders. You're not *forced* to do this, it's just that the bonuses to defence are so high that you have no choice.Similarly, the economy and politics goes from being a trivial backwater of your country to completely dominating everything you do. By the end of the game factories are absolutely *crucial* and you'll be bending over backwards to get everything working the way you want. Politics goes from completely conservative dominated to a nightmare - by the end of the game, fascist, jacobin and communist revolutions are bulk standard. And if you have a communist revolution, for example, the way you play the game has to adapt dramatically (micro-managing your economy can be a damn nightmare). In the 100 years Vic II covers, you inevitably go from being in control of your economy and your population to being terrified of them - effective strategy becomes absolutely essential to achieving your goals.So in terms of general strategic depth, this game is absolutely unrivaled. The flaws however, are myriad. Vic II was made before Paradox miraculously got good at programming games with CKII; despite being released in 2009 the graphics feel they came from about 10 years earlier. The game is *slow*. If your economy hasn't kicked off and you're not fighting a war, this is a waiting game. The first 30 years of a non-western country are even worse - the westernizing process is basically just several hours of sitting around doing absolutely nothing. The game *does* pick up towards its last half - but the first half can be really, damningly boring.There are also some major gameplay flaws that really, really break the immersion, e.g the definition of a 'great power' as the top 8 scoring countries. While this is fine in itself, 'score' takes into account prestige as much as it does military strength. It's pretty normal to see Russia lose its great power status due to a lack of prestige and be overtaken by Belgium, Bavaria or Switzerland. And then, come 1890 the first 'Great War' starts with Germany, France, Italy, and the USA on one side and Belgium and Switzerland on the other - which is an *entirely* game ruining experience. A great war is *supposed* to be a cataclysmic war that goes on for years and years and reshapes the world in the process - when it ends after a month when Germany simply walks its troops into Belgium, it feels really, really dumb.I have some other pet peeves - for example, the way the USA is hard-coded to get way more immigrants than everybody else - even other large colonial nations like Mexico or Brazil. This means that the Americas are incredibly predictable, every game. Not once have I seen something happen other than the USA becoming a top great power with the entire continent in its sphere. It's just really really dull. There's no way to play as Mexico or Brazil and try to rival the USA for dominance of the area. With that one move Paradox cut off half the world from ever being interesting.So yeah. It's a brilliant game that will drive you up the walls out of frustration. It's definitely worth playing, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥I hope Vic III is better than this.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2012
												A Grand Strategy Title by Paradox Interactive which deserves the adjective 'Grand' clearly. The objective of the game is to pick a nation and lead it to greatness. To achieve this goal you have to build up your army & industry, keep up in research, start reforms and polish your prestige. There are multiple form of governments and nearly all can be established in any country if the right conditions are met. Once you are a great power, it's also your objective to keep up that status, since there are other nations rising. But beware, the game will flood you with data. The developers tried to make the data as useful and accessible as possible, which worked (customizable pie charts to see what really is of your interest) but failed on the other side (you have to get used to it and it still is 'bulky')If you like complex strategy games and the Victorian period, you will defenitely like this one. All the features of the game are linked together and make Victoria as interesting as it is.

Here are the things I have done:-Forced China to repay debts when playing as Canada-Conquered most of Europe while playing as Greater Germany -Colonized most of the Pacific as Spain and battled my way through conquering Africa-Played as Brazil, made it to a great power and conquered a lot of South America, rivaling the US as the dominant power on the Americas-Created an economic empire playing as the NetherlandsThese are just a few I have done, and it's been a great time. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												When I found myself as liberal Russia fighting the French fascists and communist USA in the kingdom of Mexico, I knew this was a great game.Victoria 2 might be the only strategy game I would ever recommend to someone who doesn't like armies, navies or wars. While it can and does exist as a war game, the game also painstakingly details the political life of a country, and ties it to scientific discovery, economic growth and turmoil, and ethnic strife. The game begins in 1836--when the world is rural, religious, and disconnected. It ends in 1936, when democracy, communism and fascism are using radio and film to fight for the hearts and minds of millions of people.Nation-states like Germany and Italy (as well as some that never existed like Scandanavia) can be formed as much by shrewd political maneuvering as by military might. Some countries like Russia, Brazil and China are very difficult to play simply because of their own internal problems, and a new player might spend much of the game fighting reactionaries and revolutionaries that retard economic and scientific growth. Other countries like France, Japan and the USA feel almost too easy, and you wonder why the USA didn't do even better than it did in real life. It also allows you to ponder vastly different (yet ostensibly possible) histories like:-A democratic Russia-China as a great power by 1920 with the world's largest economy-A communist United States-Austria forming Greater Germany-Panjab uniting India in the late 1800s under Sikhism-The Ottomans surviving as a federated multicutural state...et cetera. I even revamped Liberia's infrastructure and education early on and went on to conquer half of Africa by 1910.The biggest problem with Victoria 2 is that with so many variables that interact with one another, the game still isn't completely fine tuned. This small amount of error becomes noticeable when you have 90% of your population joining in an Anarcho-Liberal (i.e. Libertarian) uprising. The mods available on Paradox's forums fix a lot of these issues as well as revamping and adding gameplay. If you like simulators like SimCity, strategy games like Civilization, or any developments between 1836 and 1936, buy this game.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												An extraordinary game. I questioned buying it when I first viewed it but I'm happy I did. Here are the things I have done:-Forced China to repay debts when playing as Canada-Conquered most of Europe while playing as Greater Germany -Colonized most of the Pacific as Spain and battled my way through conquering Africa-Played as Brazil, made it to a great power and conquered a lot of South America, rivaling the US as the dominant power on the Americas-Created an economic empire playing as the NetherlandsThese are just a few I have done, and it's been a great time. I recommend buying all the DLC's except the ones priced low, as they don't add much content. I have the two major DLC's and it added a lot of worthy content. Paradox Interactive makes great games and this is another trophy in the case.The only con is the economic system takes a lot of time to develop and maintain. TL;DR: This game was great and I am happy I bought it, definitely worth it!

												A very thorough and facisnating historical victorian age simulator. Very difficult to play legit (but well worth getting your true ending). content:
Posted: June 22, 2013
												Here's the Evil Scheme I came up with this afternoon... Presently I (the Glorious Tsar) have been dragged by my Prussian ally into a war with France. Considering my ambition to ensure the North German Federation never forms, I was going to abandon the Prussians, but then I stumbeled upon a most EEEvil fact...France is allied with Portugal. Thusly... I can....1. Build up the warscore to nab Mozambique, a wonderful beachead in Africa, while letting the Prussians take most of the casualties in Europe. Sadly I can't let them take ALL the casualties in Europe, because they have a tendency to sit 60,000 men in a single province and let them attrition themselves to death, and the French army is pretty damn big. Regardless, I have plenty of peasants. 2. Make a seperate peace with France that gives me Mozambique. Whilst killing a French soldier or two and fighting to slay the Portugese, manufacture a Caucus Belli on Prussia. 3. Declare war on Prussia, who will by now be decimated from the long war with France. Use Austrian support (Austria's my ally but not at all friends with Prussia) to crush the Prussians, take over some nice East German provinces, and strangle any hopes of a united germany in the cradle. Oh, and Note to Self: remember to sphere Manchuria to get the Pekeing treaty land before invading China and nabbing that goldmine I missed in the last war... Get this game. You might find yourself cackling at odd, embarrassing times... but get this game. NOW. Cheers, Tsar Strategos the Magnificent

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This is like the Advanced course for Paradox spergs like myself (Victoria 1 is the KILL YOURSELF NOW course fyi, fun but impossible to understand). It's the last game Paradox made before they changed their development process for CK2 so it suffers a but from the 'Old Paradox' ways of having the sequential expansions that act as patches. With Heart of Darkness, it's very good, though its one expansion away from really becoming as excellent as EU3 was and CK2 is and EU4 will be. It's based in a fascinating period of history and it's my favorite setting for a Paradox game because you can get the sense of the world shifting massively throughout the time period. From post-Napleonic squabbles over random crap, to the heyday of colonizing Africa and building railroads across the West, to the chaos and horror of the Great War and fascist/communist takeovers, Victoria covers it all. I really wish that we get a Victoria 3 of the same quality as CK2 and EU4 and that it comes with a EU4-V3 converter.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Is it new? Is it flashy? Is it good-looking? No, absolutely not. Despite that, it's my favourite grand strategy game of all time. I have no idea how I've put so many hours into Victoria II, but I have, and I'll keep on putting in more until a sequel comes out - which it had better, Paradox!Deceptively replayable, with an incredibly deep demographics and economics system that will take poring over a few textbooks to completely understand. Despite no country actually having truly unique gameplay elements besides some events and decisions, all of them stand out on their own due to the makeup of their populatiosn, the resources within their borders, and the geopolitical situations in which they find themselves.To give you an idea, I've put over 600 hours into this game and I still haven't gotten around to playing as Prussia even once.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Paradox sucked me in with their dynastic simulator, Crusader Kings II.  My addiction deepened with the conquest-driven Europa Universalis IV.  Then I found Victoria II.  These three games each cover distinct time periods and sport their own unique gameplay.  Vicky 2 is my favorite because of the staggering amount of nation control available to play around with.  Other reviews do a better job of detailing it, but I have found the system addictively complex but never overly-complicated.  The ability to automate trade is helping me get my feet wet without overwhelming me, and I can't wait to start messing around in there either.  Already, when I go back to play the other two games, I find myself longing for the kind of internal management capabilities only found herein.  Hooked!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												This is an excellent grand strategy game, with an ideal balance between complexity and accessibility. Of all the Paradox grand strategy games, Victoria II makes me feel most like a real, historical leader, with more methods of expansion that just military conquest, as other titles such as EU III and EU IV can feel like. The expansions are also great, with Heart of Darkness' Great War mechanic really making wars between Great Powers feel meaty and fulfilling. The game can sometimes be a little ridiculous, (such as Russia demanding Scotland as part of a peace deal with the United Kingdom, and African colonial empires often looking like random, intertwined shapes than chosive colonial territories) but the expansions again fix most of these issues with nations taking huge infamy hits for taking regions they have no claim on, and also requiring a valid reason for delaring war in the first place. On the whole, this game feels very rewarding. Your decisons feel as though they have real concequences, and no two playthroughs are the same. The learning curve is not too steep (compared to say Hearts of Iron III), meaning a few trial games will allow you to know most of the games mechanics. In conclusion, an excellent game, still being supported by the developers, that I always come back to, despite numerous other Paradox strategy games being released since its initial relsease.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Victoria II is, by all standards of modern gaming, a classic. It combines the ease of use and adaptability of past Paradox games with a dynamic, mildly fast paced action on the strategic map. Tons of decisions and political choices to make, an enthrilling political system, cool classic scenarios for the time period 1836-1936 with a very fluid flow of events. I would reccomend this title to newcomers and veterans alike, as it is one rare gem of a game these days, one that keeps you interested, engaged and involved in the action both from an industrial / economical standpoint and a more political / military one. The one rule for newcomers: DONT PANIC. It will be an experience that, in time, will most certainly grant anybody a fun time in one of History's most interesting boiling points. Play one of the major factions in the world or strive for freedom as one of the smaler ones, while reforming, adapting to the shift into the modern era, or try to destroy the seemingly untouchable spread of nationalism to remain on your Imperial seat.What more do you need?

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												It's almost as if they designed the game specifically assuming that you have the micromanagement skills of the AI. Playing as a communist or socialist country is pretty much impossible if you want to have a high industrial score, which kind of defeats the point. Migrating soldier pops mean you have to constantly micromanage armies and replace troops when they suddenly decide to move to another state (which somehow means they can no longer replinish?). There's no army template, like in EU IV, even though it could easily be managed. Naval combat is a drag, and navies take forever to build up despite little to no actual benefit of having them. The UI is tedious, the map modes lacking. I got good at the game before I could even understand how everything worked, easily westernizing as Nejd, taking over all of the Middle East, westernizing, and pretty easily getting into 6th place before my armies got too big to micromanage and Russia tore me to pieces, despite having a far inferior army. The world market is broke to♥♥♥♥♥♥ Liquor demand is through the roof, yet there's always some being thrown out while my guards wait forever to get some, making the recruitment of them impossible (there is a similar problem with demand not being high enough for advanced goods later on, like barrels for tanks). Overall, this is a good game, but it desperately needs to fix the micromanagement.

												>Recommended<Out of almost 600 hours of gameplay put into this game, it is clearly because I enjoy playing it. Victoria II is a strategy game which takes place in the aftermath of the Napoloenic Wars. It it now that the white man shows his power and intentions of ruling the world with an iron fist. You can control any nation on the planet in the 19th century. The bulding of an empire starts in Europe, play as Prussia (Germany), the birth of a new superpower, which is to flip the balance of power in Europe. The vanilla game of Vicotoria II is a fantastic adventure, form empires, control dominions and colonize the world (The scramble for Africa). I recommend giving this game a shot, it will be well worth the money, especially thanks to the fantastic mods that have been created for this game, which is to be found on various websites.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												In Victoria 2, you play as a nation for 100 years, starting in 1836. The game primarily revolves around the "pops" (a simulation of your population), who can have various jobs, purchase goods, and migrate around the world. As you play the game, you'll be industrializing your country by researching techs, building factories, and conquering other (usually less advanced) areas of the world in order to procure goods for your factories. You also have to deal with the various political ideologies which will cause your subjects to demand various government reforms, or even to openly revolt in order to attempt to enforce whatever ideology they follow (democratic reforms, communism, etc.).Pros: -fun to see an alternate history play out-pop system is well done and adds a human character to the game-interesting events, but not so many big random ones as in other games, so overall there is less luck at play-mod support. there are some excellent mods available which flesh out the game even more.Cons:-some parts of the economy simulator are kind of strange. it works ok, but feels a little unrealistic at times.-combat involves dice rolls, which imo is not the greatest thing. That being said they don't have an overwhelming effect so it isn't too luck based-doesn't have very good UI, which can be confusing.-AI can be somewhat stupid in certain situations.Overall I would recomend this game to anyone who likes longer and slower strategy games. Some important things to note for anyone interested in playing this are:1. Like all paradox games, there is no real set objective, and you are expected to set your own goals. There is a ranking system which makes it more possible to feel like you "won" by getting to the #1 spot, but it's not like say Civilization with victory conditions. If you prefer a more focused objective, this may not be the game for you.2. Be sure to purchase all the expansions. Unlike some later releases like Crusader Kings, where each new DLC is accompanied by a free patch, many of the expansions for this contain fixes to balance and such. You can still have fun without them of course, but the game may be a little strange.3. The interface is a bit complicated and can feel a bit overwhelming initially. Combined with the fact that there is no "winning", you may begin to feel like you are just sitting there doing nothing when you first play. My advice is to quickly go through the menus to get an idea of your options, and after that, don't worry about it too much and just start playing. You will likely make some stupid mistakes but overall you should be fine as long as you are playing a decently powerful country. Also, try to set smaller objectives as you go along rather than setting some huge goal at the start - this will keep things less stressful for your first game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												In Victoria 2, you play as a nation for 100 years, starting in 1836. The game primarily revolves around the "pops" (a simulation of your population), who can have various jobs, purchase goods, and migrate around the world. As you play the game, you'll be industrializing your country by researching techs, building factories, and conquering other (usually less advanced) areas of the world in order to procure goods for your factories. You also have to deal with the various political ideologies which will cause your subjects to demand various government reforms, or even to openly revolt in order to attempt to enforce whatever ideology they follow (democratic reforms, communism, etc.).Pros: -fun to see an alternate history play out-pop system is well done and adds a human character to the game-interesting events, but not so many big random ones as in other games, so overall there is less luck at play-mod support. there are some excellent mods available which flesh out the game even more.Cons:-some parts of the economy simulator are kind of strange. it works ok, but feels a little unrealistic at times.-combat involves dice rolls, which imo is not the greatest thing. That being said they don't have an overwhelming effect so it isn't too luck based-doesn't have very good UI, which can be confusing.-AI can be somewhat stupid in certain situations.Overall I would recomend this game to anyone who likes longer and slower strategy games. Some important things to note for anyone interested in playing this are:1. Like all paradox games, there is no real set objective, and you are expected to set your own goals. There is a ranking system which makes it more possible to feel like you "won" by getting to the #1 spot, but it's not like say Civilization with victory conditions. If you prefer a more focused objective, this may not be the game for you.2. Be sure to purchase all the expansions. Unlike some later releases like Crusader Kings, where each new DLC is accompanied by a free patch, many of the expansions for this contain fixes to balance and such. You can still have fun without them of course, but the game may be a little strange.3. The interface is a bit complicated and can feel a bit overwhelming initially. Combined with the fact that there is no "winning", you may begin to feel like you are just sitting there doing nothing when you first play. My advice is to quickly go through the menus to get an idea of your options, and after that, don't worry about it too much and just start playing. You will likely make some stupid mistakes but overall you should be fine as long as you are playing a decently powerful country. Also, try to set smaller objectives as you go along rather than setting some huge goal at the start - this will keep things less stressful for your first game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Victoria II is one of the lesser dreadnaughts of the Paradox Interactive fleet of grand strategy games. It builds on the concepts of Europa Universalis, allowing you to take control of a nation in 1836 and see if you can't create a place in the sun for your nation before the games end date, 1936. Now, Victoria 2 has its issues. It's immensely complex to master, but easy enough to play. You have access to more charts, sliders, and government oriented features than any other Paradox games, and rivals Hearts of Iron on that note. But there's so much more to the game than that.You have to manage your political stability; ensure all ideologies are pleased. Or you can oppress your opposition, and create a one-party state if you wish. The game features several political ideologies, each with their own style and restrictions. Each nation has its own distinct parties, all of whom have different goals and policies tailored to that nation.You also have access to large amounts of information in regards to your nation's population. You can see how many capitalists, aristocrats, soldiers(enlisted and un-enlisted), farmers, etc. you have living in your nation.A House Divided adds a new starting point in 1861, and lets you justify wars by manufacturing a reason. It also adds several new features that help non-western nations be more entertaining.Heart of Darkness focuses on warfare and the geopolitical game, adding Crisis that can escalate into world wars if not resolved, and newspapers that give you a summary of important world events.All in all? An excellent game, if you enjoy Europa Universalis, or Hearts of Iron, you're bound to find a few hours of enjoyment in Victoria 2** That's an understatement.

content:
Posted: January 28
												as a whole this is a complicated game(as expected),the economy is a total enigma and even though i try to build factorys that use my raw materials and i upgrade them only if there is demand i still end up having to close some of them down due to price drops leading to negative profit. managing to keep a positive budget without taxing above 50% can only be done if you choose the right tech order while also not overextending with the standing army expansion. what i like the most about the game is the political evolution.you might end up having almost every party type in a single game, you can also influence this but for me its more fun experimenting with different types of goverment. the battle system is similar to EU, with dice rolling , but no fire/melee phases. after installing the Historical Project Mode this might be the most fun paradox strategy game i have ever played(CK,HOI,EU).i opted to have crisis locked until 1870 so the first half of the game is more linear(scripted).  then all hell breaks loose, one war can end in white peace while another can break empires(forceing them to give away all the provinces where they dont have the primary core). rebel also seem to have more success leading to interesting countries like communist italy or fascist russia. it is still hard to overthrow the great powers but there seems to be more territorial exchanges then in the vanilla version

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Best Grand Strategy Game that i ever got my hands on!Are you looking to guide a nation through one of the most exciting periods in history? The industrial revolution brought about major changes in human society, and you have a chance of influencing the welfare of your people.This game is not only about war, diplomacy and economy! It is mostly about population, or POPs as they are called in the game. You have to balance education, military, resources, production, supply and demand, technological advances, culture and politics, in order to succeed. The possibilities are almost endless...you can try to become a Great Power with a small nation, you can try to conquer the world, you can try to turn the world fascist, communist or liberal, you can ruin a rival nation's economy, deplete it's population, conquer it, etc....All that and more, but still I couldn't help Poland get into space. Because of that, game gets a 9/10 instead of a pure 10. Fully recommend it tho!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												It's almost as if they designed the game specifically assuming that you have the micromanagement skills of the AI. Playing as a communist or socialist country is pretty much impossible if you want to have a high industrial score, which kind of defeats the point. Migrating soldier pops mean you have to constantly micromanage armies and replace troops when they suddenly decide to move to another state (which somehow means they can no longer replinish?). There's no army template, like in EU IV, even though it could easily be managed. Naval combat is a drag, and navies take forever to build up despite little to no actual benefit of having them. The UI is tedious, the map modes lacking. I got good at the game before I could even understand how everything worked, easily westernizing as Nejd, taking over all of the Middle East, westernizing, and pretty easily getting into 6th place before my armies got too big to micromanage and Russia tore me to pieces, despite having a far inferior army. The world market is broke to♥♥♥♥♥♥ Liquor demand is through the roof, yet there's always some being thrown out while my guards wait forever to get some, making the recruitment of them impossible (there is a similar problem with demand not being high enough for advanced goods later on, like barrels for tanks). Overall, this is a good game, but it desperately needs to fix the micromanagement.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												>Recommended<Out of almost 600 hours of gameplay put into this game, it is clearly because I enjoy playing it. Victoria II is a strategy game which takes place in the aftermath of the Napoloenic Wars. It it now that the white man shows his power and intentions of ruling the world with an iron fist. You can control any nation on the planet in the 19th century. The bulding of an empire starts in Europe, play as Prussia (Germany), the birth of a new superpower, which is to flip the balance of power in Europe. The vanilla game of Vicotoria II is a fantastic adventure, form empires, control dominions and colonize the world (The scramble for Africa). I recommend giving this game a shot, it will be well worth the money, especially thanks to the fantastic mods that have been created for this game, which is to be found on various websites.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2013
												Here's the Evil Scheme I came up with this afternoon... Presently I (the Glorious Tsar) have been dragged by my Prussian ally into a war with France. Considering my ambition to ensure the North German Federation never forms, I was going to abandon the Prussians, but then I stumbeled upon a most EEEvil fact...France is allied with Portugal. Thusly... I can....1. Build up the warscore to nab Mozambique, a wonderful beachead in Africa, while letting the Prussians take most of the casualties in Europe. Sadly I can't let them take ALL the casualties in Europe, because they have a tendency to sit 60,000 men in a single province and let them attrition themselves to death, and the French army is pretty damn big. Regardless, I have plenty of peasants. 2. Make a seperate peace with France that gives me Mozambique. Whilst killing a French soldier or two and fighting to slay the Portugese, manufacture a Caucus Belli on Prussia. 3. Declare war on Prussia, who will by now be decimated from the long war with France. Use Austrian support (Austria's my ally but not at all friends with Prussia) to crush the Prussians, take over some nice East German provinces, and strangle any hopes of a united germany in the cradle. Oh, and Note to Self: remember to sphere Manchuria to get the Pekeing treaty land before invading China and nabbing that goldmine I missed in the last war... Get this game. You might find yourself cackling at odd, embarrassing times... but get this game. NOW. Cheers, Tsar Strategos the Magnificent

content:

												Good God! Control the British Empire and conquer the world in this brilliant  grand strategy game! Of course you can also control many other countries, including the French ( but why?) and other such meaningless tiny countries. Rule Brittania! The choices you make feel meaningful, and the amount of control you have over running your chosen country is up to you, and can be very deep. That is one of the downsides as to start with you have no clue what to do and it's quite a steep learning curve in all aspects. Another downside is its many DLCS, which are mostly pointless,but if you can get them really cheap on sale, why not? Overall it is a great strategy game and offers unparalleled in-depth 19th century Empire building greatness! Enjoy and have another cup of tea!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												A magnificent game, accompanied by inspiring music and the feeling of dominating an entire continent as your backwater country develops into a greater form of itself. Singleplayer is marvellous and ignoring some problems with the budget not showing the correct calculations, it works without a flaw! It mainly consists of you, the ruler of this country, attempting to 1. survive as a country; 2. strive to achieve everything necessary for the prosperity of your country; 3. resist the liberal and socialist threats to your absolute monarchy (unless you make the very poor choice of a democracy as your country). This "campaign" is very interesting in itself and completely sufficient for hours of entertainment and excitement. The multiplayer does however present a problem. Only LAN multiplayer is simple, trying to play with other friends requires one of those rather dubious multiplayer port-forwarding programmes, ones I do not have positive experience with (although others will argue that they are perfect). The games themselves work very smoothly, if playing with friends it is also more pleasurable to negotiate when to pause the game. A major setback however, is the cost of the game, but I believe it is worth the expense (with the "Heart of Darkness" DLC). The game, if one looks beyond its initial complexity and unexiting appearance, is thoroughly enjoyable, very engaging and a good source of some general knowledge. It is also very entertaining how small, regional conflicts can grow. An example I can give from personal experience is the "War of the Bavarian Conquest of East Switzerland". I, as Bavaria, desired to grow my territories and thus declared war on Switzerland. My Austrian ally joined me in my war. My army was intially destroyed by Switzerland (by some miracle) and Austria heavily intervened, destroying the entire Swiss army. France did not fail to notice this situation, and declared war on my alliance. Switzerland promptly surrendered and East Switzerland was now Bavarian. The Bavarian empire had begun. I had no further interest in the war and negotiated peace with France. My war was now being led by Austria against France, the combat of whom led to a mutural destruction of their respective armies.Utterly, utterly magnifivent game, it deserves recognition and the cost!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												OK, I understand♥♥♥♥♥♥now.It's a pretty great game. It basically does anything you could imagine a strategic country simulator doing, and if it doesn't, everyone and their brother has made a mod to fix it. The game starts in 1836 (though you can start in 1861 with the House Divided scenario pack), and you are given the option to play as any nation which existed at that time. Given enough patience and strategic planning, you can form other nations. If you play as one of the divided Italian states (Two Sicilies, Papal States, etc.), once you develop, annex or sphere your neighbors, you can unite into a single Italy (or just wait for an Italian Nationalist rebellion if you're lazy af).If you play as Greece, you can snag a few chunks of the Ottoman Empire and restore the Byzantine Empire. If you play as Prussia you can form the North German Federation, German Empire, etc. etc. etc., so variety is definitely a strong suit. People playing as Democratic Republics such as the US might have hard times keeping the economy running as you can only make tariffs so high in those governments (though this problem didn't last long for me because Reactionaries took over and made the U.S. a Presidential Dictatorship in which elections were outlawed and you could tariff to your Authoritarian heart's content) but eventually you learn, as I did. The game ends in 1935 iirc, but you can install mods that allow you to play into World War 2 and beyond. It's a 10/10 game. Even though the tutorials are almost useless.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Very deep Paradox grand strategy game set in the Victorian era of industrialisation and railways, in which you need to manage your populace, industry and politics to ensure your empire thrives. This period was also a brutal peroid of mechanical warfare with massive established nations fighting global wars. Although the other Paradox games like EU4 and CK2 are all unique in themselves I do find them a little bit repetitive because the gameplay a matter of witnessing new events and fighting wars, there is often not that much to do when not in conflict otherwise. CK2 has the advantage of a great intrigue system and EU4 has lovely graphics and GUI, but this Victoria 2 game has depth! It keeps you thinking on your feet all the way through to the late game and so far I have not had any time when I havent had a lot to do. So for me Victoria 2 is the Paradox game I love the most, I think its the only game where I cant see any gameplay flaws at all, I love the era, and I love the depth of the game which is unrivalled in any strategy game I have played to date.Watch Quill18's Japan Vic2 game on Youtube and I dare you not be be intrigued.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												When I first tried to run the game it wouldn't work but there is a posted fix for Vic II in the forums. After I did this fix the game runs fine now YAY!  Now I can get busy on the game and post a review about the game itself once i've played it enough.Ok now after I have reviewed the full tutorial and played my first game I am going to post a real review.I decided to go over the whole tutorial before playing, I figured it wouldn't all stick one time through (it is a lot) but I would get a general clue as to everything in the game. The game does have a steep learning curve, but after my first try I say it's worth it. It's a very involving game trying to really run everything in a country.  Politics, Industry, Income, Population, army and Technolgy. I did try to move a little too fast in acquiring new territory and got myself in hot water and ended up losing. But, I had so much fun trying to keep my people happy and budget balanced along with trying to build up infrastructure that I can't wait to try again. I will be going over a few things in the tutorial first. I haven't played with the DLC content as yet. But, I highly recommend this game if you love in depth strategy and don't mind actually having to do tutorials and maybe watch some videos too.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2
												Victoria II is a grand strategy game by Paradox, a development studio with a fetish for grand strategy based in historical settings. After clocking in 109 hours, I feel confident in calling it one of my favorite games.The historical period, the gameplay mechanics of running an economy and managing politics and waging war is very well done, the design, the music, it's all superb!However, there are complaints to be had.Firstly, the Infamy syatem. It's actually a good system, working similary to World Tension in HoI4 or Coalitions in EU4. Infamy is gained by several actions, such as having war goals discovered by the international community, removing nations from your sphere, certain event options, etc. The issue with the system is that once your Infamy reaches 25.00, a coalition WILL come after you. I feel that the limit for that should be 50 or 40, perhaps 35. This would allow for a much more active experience in the game.Secondly, DLC. Vic2 is one of those games where the DLC is a MUST. So, you'd have to purchase not only Vic2, but A House Divided and Heart of Darkness for the full experience. I got the full Vic2 bundle while it was on sale, but I cannot deny that the DLCs' necessity and price is an issue (a prevalent issue with most, if not all, Paradox titles).Aside from those two grievences, the game is highly entertaining and intellectually stimulating. If you like grand strategy...Why are you reading this? Go get it already. Stop reading and buy Victoria II. NOW, I SAY!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												This game is NOT for everyone; it is mind numbingly complex, rewarding careful planning. I can't say that I have played much of it yet, but I have played a lot of Hearts of Iron III as Germany, France, UK, Soviets, and the US. What I learned from HOI3 is not only is the US the player to be, but starting in 1936 is NOT early enough. That realization has led me to V2. In 1836 the US has not yet reached the goal of Manifest Destiny. The West is still wild, much of it held by Mexico. The Civil War has not been fought, and the goal that I have as the US player is to avoid it altogether. The Grand Campaign extends right through the First World War. Instead of practicing isolationist policies, I want to see the US become "world cop" as soon as possible. Taking that position in HOI3 worked for me, and I want to see that approach work in this game. For me the biggest mistake of World War II occured in 1936 when the US and the Allies let the fascists overthrow Republican Spain. Defending Spain would have made the Allied position MUCH stronger in 1940. Similarly, avoiding the Civil War would have made the US much stronger in the next century.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												Victoria II, yet another masterful game from the company that dictates the "Grand Strtegy" genre. This game has many realistic situations and options the allow for countless hours of gameplay. Ofter times, I think to myself "Where did my entire day go" while playing. Granted that overall the game is amazing, it does have some flaws. Rebels are a serious issue that Paradox desperately needs to fix in Victoria III (if we ever get it). I'll go over some general pros and cons of this game:PROS-Great gameplay-Pick any country and guide them through history (or alternate history)-Great powers have a ton of decisions-Easy to mod-TONS of great/fun mods to play-Mods patch issues with the vanilla game-Every country offers a different expirience CONS-Rebels arouse too often and in way to large numbers (I've had over 3/4 of my population become rebels)-Populations are unrealistic (China is the only country exceeding 1 million population)-The warscore is broken (Warscore measures how well you are doing in a war and the higher it is, the better deals you can get during a peaceoffer. However, sometimes you will be over the required warscore and the country will not surrender even if you have 100% of their provinces under your control.)-Countries with a low starting literacy rate fall far behind in technology-The UK never leaves the #1 spot on the country ranking-Rebels don't make sense (for example, after you formed Germany you will get "Prussian Nationalists" which want to liberate Prussia from Germany. Historically, it was Prussia and the Prussian people who wanted to form Germany in the first place.)***THERE ARE MODS THAT FIX A LOT OF THE CONS/ISSUES***

												A very contrarian veiw of history that really makes you realize how backwards europeans are. The best countries to start out as are Advanced african ones like Sokoto so you can create your colonial empire and bring civilization to the Europeans. Chinese are also a good start and can become the number one industrial opwer in a year or two. The UK should only be attempted by really experienced players because their empire is spread out and they are uncivilized and have almost no technology. A good middle ground is probabbly the Ottoman empire who have some tech problems but are civilized like the Africans.Black man's burden simulator 1836.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												Ok, this is going to be a difficult review.  On the one hand, I am sure that this game is very satisfying experience to anyone who can understand it.  However, on the other hand, this is not a friendly game to anyone not familiar with the genre bout would like to experience it.You can read the tutorials the game provides you and they are very detailed and tell you everything about everything in the panals up top but they don't do a good job of explaining how it all meshes together into a game.  It's like trying to fly a jet while reading the instruction manual on what all the buttons do.  It may be comprehensive, but you are no closer to learning how to fly it then when you started.I've watched several let's play "How to play this game for beginners" and I am still no closer to understanding then I was when I started.  I've also read several sites trying to explain it all to no avail.  Everyone starts out doing exactly what the tutorial does.  Explaining for a full hour what all the top panels do.  It still does not help me.  In fact, I usually start nodding off when they get to the diplomatic screen...This game needs a "Practice Game for Newbs" where it kind of holds your hand as you play showing you what you need to do or what you can do when certain events start happening.  Your armies not getting the supplies they need?  Here's what you need to do or here's a few things that you can do to help with that.If this game had something like that, I would probably give this game a thumbs up but instead, I need to give it a thumbs down.

												if your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												One of the most detailed modern civilization simulators available, Victoria II is all about economics and European "balance of power" politics. A big part of the game is guiding your nation through its industrial revolution and transitioning from an economy that relies on skilled craftsmen to one that can sustain huge factories. The game does a good job of creating a dynamic interaction between the economy, politics, and society. Don't expect too much of an overt narrative though - as in Europa Universalis, the story of your nation will be created through numbers, charts, and events. How you frame the story relies mostly on your own imagination - kind of like making your own head canon. Notable challenges include recreating Japan's rise to power through the Meiji Restoration, weathering the American Civil War, and building the British Empire. There's plenty of room to break history too! Fans of the Crusader Kings or Europa Univeralis series will know that Paradox is really good at creating systems that allow you to have fun rewriting history. You can create a communist United Kingdom, fight for Indian or Southeast Asian independence and industrial power, or build an empire to resist the Western colonization of Africa. Some histories are harder to rewrite than others - but this is a game that rewards practice and experience, and with enough of those almost anything is possible.Victoria II comes with a "brick wall" style learning curve - if you've played Europa Universalis before and can remember what it was like to first learn how to be good at that game, expect to experience that again. I'm still not very good at this game with only 14 hours registered, but it's fun (despite the frustration) to learn a new system. If you don't like feeling frustrated, I suggest looking up tutorials online because this game's systems are very complex for a newcomer. On the other hand, if you like learning new things and don't mind feeling like a total idiot, or if you don't mind having to scrap whole games' worth of progress to start over, then just dive in and experiment. Trust me, the game will let you know when you've lost. The huge variety of settings and the specific challenges that different nations face ensure that you'll never be lacking inspiration for a new game.Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm off to create a Romanian superpower to unite the Balkan states.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												Victoria II is a grand strategy game which spans one hundred years of history, from 1836 to 1936. The game allows a player to start as any nation which existed in 1836 (or 1861, if the DLC "A House Divided" has been downloaded and installed, and yes, that includes the CSA). The player can explore any avenue that they wish to pursue for achieving the lofty goal of "Great Power" status. One can dominate the Industrial Revolution(s) by becoming a factory-filled powerhouse; conquer every nation around them through decades of war; colonize Africa, Asia, and the Pacific islands; or skillfully manipulate their scientific progress and culture to become one of the most advanced nations on the planet. None of this, however, is in any way easy. Victoria II's excellence comes at the cost of enormous complexity. It can be daunting for a new player to memorize the various intricacies of economics, politics, diplomacy, and the like. Furthermore, the game is built to accurately simulate the chosen time period, and that means that rival nations will attempt to check the player at every turn. Your population's happiness and your national budget are also large concerns. Money is difficult to come by without hard work (or cheesing the system), and if the general populace finds itself outraged by your decisions one too many times, they'll take up arms and demonstrate to you why our modern world has so few monarchies anymore. Whatever goal you set your sights on, you will have to fight for it. It make take a long time to gain enough experience to excel at this game.That doesn't mean that Victoria II isn't a fun game. On the contrary. It's an incredibly fun game. The thrills of just barely beating a rival to that last colonial province, starting as a small country and forming a larger nation like Italy or Germany, or just messing around with history in general are what give Victoria II its charm. No game is ever exactly the same, so each campaign is a new adventure. Who knows what might happen? Maybe Sweden will become a global communist superpower. Maybe Mexico will start the Second World War by invading Greek Nigeria. Maybe Afghanistan will become world-renowned for its brilliant artists and rich cultural developments, while France lives in infamy as the nation that destroyed the USA. Whatever path you choose to lead your nation down, you can rest assured in two things: One, it will be a long and hard battle, as it was for any nation during those times to ascend to greatness. Two, it will most certainly be worth it.A final caveat: The base game by itself is somewhat...flawed. Purchasing the DLCs "A House Divided" (which adds Civil War content, revamps the economic and political systems, adds casus belli fabrication, and more) and "Heart of Darkness" (which vastly improves the colonization system, adds international crises which can be resolved through negotiation or combat, and other things) will lead to a much, much more rewarding experience.

The huge variety of settings and the specific challenges that different nations face ensure that you'll never be lacking inspiration for a new game.Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm off to create a Romanian superpower to unite the Balkan states.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												I went with the U.K for some time, appearently infamy doesn't matter with them since they are just so big of an empire that all you need to do is wait for white peace and then declare war and spread not caring about going over even 100 infamy. Evntually I satrt a new game go with U.K and play as Canada. I got anihilated by the U.S and U.K is doing nothing so I am not doing that again, unless I were to make a mod doing something about that... Well after that I tried Japan, after the first try with them I had Korea and parts of Arabia, then stopped playing Japan for whatever reason. Then I tried Siam, I got beaten by the Chinese for expanding right next to them.Then I try South America because Risk logic. Argentina, Chile, and Brazil are so good in my opinion. Now playing as these countries I ought to pay attention to Infamy since the one time I was Brazil and went too far then everyone declares war on me, never played Brazil again. So Argentina ends up being my favourite country and is the first thing I mod and I made infamy nothing to worry about by giving me cores, and then I formed a new nation just because mods, flags never work in my mods for some amount of reasons. Well I end up being a nation that has the lands of Argentina, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay, and poor ol' Bolivia. I remember the one time I made a game allied with everyone in South America except for Bolivia and made a non-reasonable crusade against them, five years later I just annex them then betray just about everyone in the south of South America.Now I have tried Mexico a few times and none of the times have I succesfully taken Texas, one time I have complete control over Texas but then U.S interferes nearly last second, I really want to make mods that will make the U.S not so full of military power. Also the only reason why I would ever suport C.S.A. Well this is my experience on the game but to make this an actual review, the game isn't all world domination like I originally thought, no instead you wait for Cassus-Belli I think it's called and then you decide if you want to declare war without gaining infamy, or go ahead and get infamy it's really up to you. Being a Great Power gives you a great advantage when it comes to diplomacy, sometimes it can be fun to get a lot of money coming in and just looking through the wars supporting whichever side by giving war subsidies. Sometimes it's hard to industrialize most likely because you're political party won't pay for building factories, well if your a HM government you can change to some party that will let you or somehow get a revolt and change governments that way. It can be fun colonising but the French are just too quick with colonising in my opinion. Playing as a low country can be fun as a challenge yet it is frustrating, especially when some country annihilates your only hopes of winning wars. Encouragement is useful yet I feel as if it is something barely thought of.Well that's pretty much all, my advice would be if you're going against an uncivilized nation or country, whatever. Check if any Great Power has friendly relations with them or has them in sphere, now if none do and you are not going to wait for a Cassus-Belli or you know you are not going to since I so far only get those by border incidents then declare war through "demand concession" way less infamy given. There is also demand protectorate or something, yeah do that too.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I have yet to try other Paradox strategies, but I can already say I'm really enjoying  Victoria II	 . Before buying the steam version I had a physical copy which I got for free from a deal. It had both Victoria II + A House Divided and Victoria I + Revolutions. What made me buy the steam version was that I could not enhance the retail edition with Heart of Darkness which is a must for a full Vicky experience. I just wasn't sure if the copy of HoD I could buy was compatible with it. Go figure, I bought the steam version alongside two DLCs. No regrets.Before you actually think of buying this or any other Paradox developed game you must take one thing into consideration.  Paradox grand strategies are known for their rather steep-learning curve  I'm looking at you, Hearts of Iron III...	 and rather confusing interface . While the tutorial might sort of give you a little pat to the right way it's possible that you may want to look up a guide on YouTube, as the former doesn't cover some important topics such as  Colonizing	 which plays a vital role in becoming a great power later on. After you know what the hell you're doing you will really enjoy this game. It's fun to lead your country becoming a contender in the ever so harsher competition for world dominance. If you're into grand strategies then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Victoria 2 is an excellent GSG title which will have your mouth gasp at it's complexity. Victoria 2 has a fully working emulated world market, which changes dynamically according to events that happen in your world that YOU control. For instance, let's say you go to war against the US, this would increase the demand for, say, machine parts, gun parts, etc etc. The complexity of this game put me off it for a bit, but once they get the EU4 -> Vic2 convertor going I am sure to learn it fully. Great game, as far as I am concerned.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												As I have said to Johnny, fun is not the correct word to use when describing paradox games. Watching your nation industrialise, guiding it through colonial wars of aggression and, most importantly of all, watching as your nations colours spread across the map are not fun activities. They are however incredibly interesting and quite enthralling. Play as shogunate Japan and meld them into the new British Empire. Take the CSA and "live your life". Create an Austrian empire stretching from the Baltic sea to the Adriatic. All of this can be done, and has been done by myself.As this is my favourite period in history, I may be a little biased, but I would have to say that this game fights with Civ 5 for the top seat at my table.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Update:In a nutshell, Victoria II can be considered the greatest Grand Strategy game ever made if not for it's lack of update and outdated GUI. Pros:- Ability to manage internal and external politics of your country as well as your population- Ability to manage production and good as well as trade- Ability to lead armies and research a varied tech tree Cons- Lack of updates makes mods the only avenue for bugfixes- Lack of mod updates as modders moved on to more supported games like Crusader Kings II and Europa Universalis IV- Outdated graphics and GUI makes some actions seem convoluted. Bear in mind, even with the cons here, it still trumps both CK2 and EU4 in terms of re-playability and the variety of strategies you can employ. The only problem now is the heart of the game, which are mods are sadly lacking.It is still a recommendation for the game nonetheless. You wouldn't have truly played a Grand Strategy game until you've played Victoria 2. I'm certain Victoria 3 will be one of the greatest Grand Strategy game of the decade if it ever comes out.------------------------------------Old review:I've played CK2, EU4 and Victoria 2, the few more recent Grand Strategy games from Paradox. I can say that Victoria 2 is the "de facto" Grand Strategy game from Paradox and probably of all recent ones too. You can delve deep into the economics of your nation while managing your diplomacy of your next conquest, all this while making an industrial powerhouse out of your population.In short, if you're a fan of Grand Strategy games. Get this until EU4 expansions fixes all of its micromanagement problems (fleet/buildings etc).Oh, I've been playing Civ all this while and I'm never going back to them after playing this.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												I originally was planning on getting Crusader Kings 2, but I was glad I purchased this instead. Made by the same devloper and publisher who made Crusader Kings 2, this game does not dissapoint. The game revolves around the turn of the century in the mid-late 1800s to the mid 1900s; following real-time events and being very detailed to the last aspect of the game. It may take a little bit to figure out the game's mechanics, but once you do the possiblities are endless. I remember first playing as the CSA (Confederate States Of America) in the house divided expansion, and took over the rest of the US. The only problem I had with the game is that it is almost unplayable without the two expansions "A House Divided" and "Heart Of Darkness." The other expansions are just soundtracks or military skins that are utterly useless, unless you really want them. The music is very good; with some songs reaching cinematic levels of quality. The game is over all one of my favorites with endless possiblities, great/very detailed game mechanics, and a very strong story following real-time events that you can change. If you don't want to empty your wallet for games like Crusader Kings 2 or Europa Universalis, don't want a Historical RPG that's extremely hard, and want to shape the world in your image, then this game is for you.9/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												Way to blow 16 or so hours in Victoria II.Step 1: Start game as Mexico.Step 2: Conquer Texas and maintain your North American territory.Step 3: Combat the British in several wars as they try to invade glorious Mexico.Step 4: Conquer Hawaii.Step 5: Become Socialist.Step 6: Late industrial growth while waiting for world powers to forgive Mexico.Step 7: Become a world power.Step 8: Conquer Korea for glorious Mother Mexico.Step 9: Aid the CSA in American Civil War.Step 10: Marvel at how the Civil War ends in a white peace.Step 11: Suppress communist revolt.Step 12: Switch sides and help the Union in the Second American Civil War.Step 13: Make no territorial gains, but secure US as ally.Step 14: Continue to combat nation-wide communist revolts forever.Step 15: Game ends with Socialist Mexico as the eighth great power.Extra Step: Plot to go through again and let Communists win.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Victoria 2 is by far my all time favourite game. Period. It is a grand strategy game set in the dawn of the Victorian era. France has been defeated just twenty years prior, the Ottoman Empire is dying, German nationalism is on the rise, and the British Empire is the greatest power in the world. In this game, you can click on any of the 150+ countries on the map and hop right in. if you are into strategy, then definetely pick it up (with all the expansions!). After learning the ropes, you will likely fall in love with this game

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Absolute masterpiece of a game. There are a few problems here and there but this game tries to grasp so many concepts at once and it does so beautifully.The game is not as complex as many people will have you believe. There are a lot of statistics but it is through these statistics that the game comes alive.You can see how your population is divided into these separate social classes, what their concerns are, how well they are doing, their religion, political views, etc. And it fits extremely well with the period because the 19th century was a great period of innovations and ideas.Different political parties have different abilities and functions.Factories can built built directly or coaxed into creation. Unemployment is bad, etc...Any fan of a nation simulator should get this game. DLC is recommended/required.

But one minor problem for people with not much time and just want a quick game. It is an One Hundred Year game and you can choose up to a 5x speed which is about 5 days per 3.5 seconds. Also the huge learning curve. What I suggest is getting it but taking your time on time off to learn and play and a huge game is just so much fun. A great game and also try games like the upcoming East vs West which is the 5th game in the Paradox Grand Campaign which I'm playing to start very soon once I get Europa Universalis 4 which I also recommend. There is also Hearts of Iron 4 that comes out later in 2014 and then there is Crusader Kings 2 all have huge learning curves but all once learned are just plain amazing games. I hope you enjoy every part of it! :D

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Kings of Strategy, Paradox Interactive's late modern era game. Historical events and options are plentiful. A shorter timespan than most PI games, only 100 years, from 1836 to 1936, as opposed to the four centuries that Crusader Kings and Europa Universalis have. Starting just at the rise of Pax Britannica, just after the falls of the French and Spanish Empires, there's so much to do in this game. Form the German Empire. Try and stay an Absolute Monarchy through the rise of Liberalism, Socialism, Communism and Fascism. Act out America's Manifest Destiny and partake in the Civil War. Play the Chinese Empire and try and modernise and resist foreign influences. Play the Ottoman Empire and prevent your backslide into historical obscurity. There's so much to do, and you've got to make your own goals. In usual Paradox style there's a ton of super-complex systems that you need to know, but if you get a handle on it, there's so much depth and replayabilitiy to be done.
