number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												It's the year 1904. Bohemia-Moravia has cried out for independence and I, Great Britain, have answered their call. To my surprise, France and Russia joined Austria-Hungary in keeping Bohemia-Moravia oppressed. This will be a great war.By the year 1910, my nation had built the first tank, aeroplane, and vehicle factories. Out production was the third best in the world, but our manpower....Our manpower was unmatched. As the nation grew, I did everything I could to make my population love their home. I wanted immigrants and did anything I could to attract them. My government became liberal, and even though my military spending is lower due to the "anti-military" liberal policy, my population is the highest by 65 million. The sheer number and quality of Great Britains soldiers have allowed me to take northern France and defend India from Russia. However, France has gas, and I have no defense against gas. I have lost double the men that France. While I am winning the war, I may not be if my researchers can't formulate a defense soon.This is Victoria 2. Probably one of, if not the most amazing game I've ever played.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Pretty much my introduction to all things Paradox. While the game has a significant learning curve - and arguably some game mechanics that feel either dated or just needlessly bothersome, it is definitely worth a look.You don't even need to play a major country to have fun - You can easily play a small nation systematically manipulating the stock markets by buying goods while they are at a surplus and selling them off when a war breaks out, or new technology pushes for mass consumption.It also has some of the best music in a game of its genre hands down, which definitely helps with long game sessions.

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I'd like to give Victoria 2 a positive review, but at this time, I just cannot bring myself to do so. Positives of the game in my eyes:-Economics are fantastic-If you like EU4, but want a deeper level of economics, then this game certainly fills that role perfectly.-Colonization is fun-Pretty self explanitory here. Competing with other great powers for the rich coast of Africa is a fun contest of will and strength.-Taking a nation from "civilized" to "Great Power" is amazing-I took Japan and made it into a great power, easily overpowering Spain and the USA in the conquest of China.Negatives of the game in my eyes:-Horrible amount of popup events-I understand that you get random events, sometimes negative and sometimes positive, but when you get the same dang event popping up fifty-seven times in twenty minutes, it makes for a lousy impression. I've heard that its due to some of the DLCs, but that's still no excuse for this to occur so often.-Great powers gang up- You can be helping the smallest of nations with some small war, and suddenly you'll find yourself facing the UK and bloody every other great power on Earth for no other reason than the fact that you're at war. Others may find this realistic, I find it annoying, especially if I'm the one being attacked by the smaller nation.-Literacy rate makes or breaks you-I realize that I do not yet quite understand the full concept of literacy in Victoria 2, but I hate that you can have a full education budget and dedicate all of your resources to try and build up the literate people, but it will still take you decades (and often longer) to go up a few percentage points.-Unstable game-Pretty self explanitory. This game crashes every so often, though it the biggest complaint with this is that mods cause it to crash like a boss.After all is said and done, do I regret buying this game? No, I certainly do not. However, I do think that you should ask yourself if you like grand strategy games and if you are willing to look past the flaws. It can be a really fun experiance, but you'll have to not get annoyed at the crashes or the endless popup events.

content:
Posted: March 30
												I enjoyed it.. when it worked. Unfortunately this game is broken as far as I can tell. At the moment it crashes on launch and I still don't know why as I've done all the the troubleshooting in their "Discussions'. Not only that but it crashes pretty frequently even when iit does work and my pc is only about a year old!Gameplay is interesting although as someone who hasn't played a lot of these types of games, it was often unclear how some things affected the overall result. And I expected the navy to play a much larger role due to the era but it can pretty much be skipped if you're not surrounded by water. Also it kinda has that feeling when you play a board/card game with your friend and their SO and they automatically team up against you and won't do anything to really threaten each other. Except "your friend and their SO' is pretty much all of the AI in this game. The battles they have seem somewhat just tokens and the alliances are solid. Not once did any of my "Allies' back me up when I was being attacked or attacking. Maybe I'm just playing wrong but I feel like that is something the game should point out or explain why things are happening.So to sum up, I enjoyed it and I'd probably still play it if it wasn't broken but it IS broken and it takes a long time to learn to play and an even longer time to find out you've done something that has made the match unwinnable.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19
												Game is simply too buggy and unstable in its current iteration. It seems as though it may be fun if it worked somewhat consistently, but having tested it on now 5 different machines, I have 2 machines it will never properly start a game on, and 3 in which it crashes every 4 minutes on average (longest run about 15 minutes).All 5 machines more than meet the requirements for the game, and one of them was on a brand new install of windows 10 (a machine I use just for these test purposes).I have read that deleting the contents of the map/cache folder from both the Steam library location and the users documents helps the issue, but in my testing this has yet to help in over 2 dozen attempts; if anything, this seems to make the time between crashes shorter on the rare occasions it will actually load a game, though that is likely simply a fluke.This game came highly reviewed from friends of mine who played it long ago, so I hope that whatever is causing these issues is resolved. For now, however, this is simply an exercise in frustration, and I would not even consider the game to be playable.

number of helpful: 32 of 71 people (45%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												I would NOT recommend Victoria II, however...I WOULD recommend Victoria II if you have the two major DLCs, "A House Divided" (AHD) and "Heart of Darkness" (HOD).Even with these, Victoria II is still a bit of a mess - but fortunately not the huge steaming♥♥♥♥♥♥pile that the vanilla game is.Seriously, for all Vicky's flashy stastics, historical nerd porn, and awesome technology tree, it has MAJOR flaws, and I mean pretty ♥♥♥♥ing major flaws.I'm surprised certain design elements got past the final stages of development for this game. And, furthermore, considering HOD is essential for at least slightly realistic battles and therefore more fair wars, HOD is a paid patch. There is a big problem with feedback. One of your provinces is being sieged? Good luck finding out which one it is in your massive global empire. Oh, and that unit finished that siege eight months ago. Oh, suddenly we're losing money. Oops, forgot to upgrade that colonization effort to a protectorate and now somebody else has taken it.Even with HOD, the colonization mechanics are still rubbish at best. There is no real historical accuracy at all. Now, I know it's a game where you're supposed to create your own history, and that's fine, but why the ♥♥♥♥ is Russia colonizing Ethiopia?The diplomacy system is S H I T E. It's simply awful. The diplomacy points system makes little to no sense for the era and the 'Very Unlikely/Unlikely/Maybe/Likely/Very Likely' system is terrible. But the worst aspect of this game are your allies. They are pointless.Playing as Portugal (which in EUIV is a fun, challenging nation to play and has an interesting history in the Victorian era), I sent an alliance offer to Britain. hey accepted with 'Likely'. The Netherlands almost immediately declares war on me and Britain ♥♥♥♥s off like a little ♥♥♥♥♥. Not only would this NEVER HAPPEN in real life considering Britain and Portugal have been allies since the late 1300s, but also because they are both enemies of the Dutch in this time period.And guess what? Suddenly France, Spain, every man and his dog are at war with me. Not fair. I lost all my colonies in Africa and lost Douros to the bloody Spanish.That sucks. The AI really hates you in this game. No joke. I think it genuinley hates the player.Something I will praise is the economy system and the factory/industry mechanic, which are both unique and well done. War itself, if balanced, is actually pretty fun and managing the politcal system is rewarding and captivating.But, this game is outdated and mostly broken. I would say you should wait until those Swedish ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s at Paradox release Victoria III, or buy EUIV if it's on sale. Despite it's flaws, Victoria II can be fun if played with both of the major DLCs and a lot of patience. Oh, and maybe some cheats because sometimes the game is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I feel like I need to send it to a mental hospital.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												I generally like strategy games, and I thought I would like this game but I really can't take it anymore. Part of the reason I tried this game is because it had a more complex economy, but the economy makes no sense.  When there is more demand than supply on the world market instead of the price increasing until supply meets demand, the game gives the countries with more "prestige" the products.  As a result, if you are a smaller country there are certain products that you can never access on the world market.  To build certain units like artillery, you need liquor and I waited for over fifty years trying to get liquor but I could never get it.There are only a handful of levers you have to control your country (although you have full control of the military) which makes some sense, but the levers you have available are very limited and kind of strange.  You get bombarded by events that happen in your country that that you get to choose a response that will nudge your country in a certain direction, but the choices often make no sense and the same choices pop up again, and again, and again, and again.  You get constatnly bombarded by silly questions so often that it drives me nuts.The tech tree is pretty dull, but I like that when you research a new tech, there are technologies that will be discovered later as a chance discovery.  In a nutshell, playing it just made me want to beat my head against a wall or go play Civilizations.

number of helpful: 12 of 31 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												I had high hopes for Vicky 2, since CK2 and EU4 are pretty solid games.  Vicky 2 is great when it comes to the economic build up and the complexities of Great Power diplomacy, but it falls (extremely) when military and basic AI comes into the fray.  Military is very messy and unorganized, something that I was surprised to see in a Pdox game.  I have heard players say it is micromanagement, but it isn't.  It comes down to very bad game design right down to the UI.  It is no wonder why the series hasn't had any rumors of a sequel since this was poorly executed.  If  a Vicky 3 ever arrives (unlikely) then I hope it takes cues from the solid vision from EU4.

												To start off, I don't normaly complain about games, and playing games such as CK2 and EU4 I was expecting a great game from Paradox. I paid £15 for the base game, but when I started playing I found there was barely anything in the game. It was like EU4 but with only the basic features. So, I thought I would pay the extra £15 for the Hearts of Darkness expansion, but when it downloaded the DLC, the launcher wouldn't launch. I then deleted the game and re-downloaded but it did the same. I restarted my computer then deleated the game, re-downloaded and realunched. The launcher worked and I happily clicked play. I then discovered that you need A House Divided to play. A game I wanted to play for £15 will end up costing me over twice as much and even then it still might not work. The thing that annoyed me was that steam said you could play HOD without AHD.IF YOU WANT TO BUY, BUY IN A STEAM SALE. DONT BUY IN SEPERATE PARTS!

number of helpful: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Do you feel like watching 4 hours of tutorials and reading guides for another 2?  If so, this game is for you!I normally wouldn't complain about investing the time to play a game... if the game actually paid off.  I found myself bored quickly bored.  There are several other games that have much better mechanics and keep game play interesting.  This is not Sid Meiers Civilization -- and in my opinion that would be the game to recommend.When I compare this to other strategy games, I see how the developers tried really hard, tried to add an original spin on things, and failed, failed, failed.  I suppose it's an honest effort compared to franchises that have bigger budgets to work with.  I really think this game could have been great if it were more intuitive, quicker paced with better action/events, and threw in some cut scenes and an expanded diplomatic section.The basic plot is to play as any country in the Victorian era.  The game really centers around the big powers of the day -- Britain, Russia, Germany, and a few others including America.  The game seems built to cater to players who will automatically pick a big power.  If, however, you pick a smaller or less influential country -- game play is like eating dry toast.There is a research system for "national focus" which lets you open up new technology and discoveries.  The options are well-thought out and historically appropriate.  The major flaw is the slow speed to finish one item of research.  I don't see how anyone can unlock and achieve all the national focus items even at the drawn-out slow pace of the game.  If we are being realistic, 2015 would not be 2015 as we know and live in it if it were based on the research portion.  So... fail.  Perhaps, there is another way, but with the hours of other things you have to learn, a dull tutorial, and lack of intuitivity, this just isn't happening.The political decision tree is very interesting with well thought out social and political reforms.  One's in-game choices will alter the political leanings of your population.  The problem I have with the political system is that many of the options are unavailable with many countries.  I suppose this is somewhat.... somewhat... realistic, however, it often leaves the player frustrated when trying to progress.Production is much the same as production in many other strategy games.  You import, export, and stockile resources.  You build factories if you are under a government system that can, or wealthy capitalists build them for you.  If you need a certain resource, you either buy it at market price or you go take over a country that has that resource.  Though, aggressive players might have advanced tactics for taking over the world, the game doesn't make hostile takeovers simple nor easy.  Also, it feels that if you produce goods and have spent your in-game time researching industrialization you are painting a bullseye on your back.  With the slow pace of research, you simply cannot have a strong military and a strong industry unless you are a super power.  This was how I lost Switzerland.... poor cuckoo clock makers.The military aspect of the game, by default, somewhat follows what happened in history.  Depending on what country you are playing you'll either be severely handicapped or very powerful.  The military options are decent and much more straight-forward than other game mechanics.  When I say straight forward, I do not mean easy.  Some countries seem fated to certain takeover despite a well thought out strategy.The diplomatic options were appealing to me.  The options included do expand the diplomatic choices a player can make.  This would be great if it weren't based on a points spent system that crawls far too slowly.There are some unique aspects to the mechanics of the game such as population militancy and choices that advance or curtial liberlism.  I am sure if I had more time to let my eyes glaze over waiting for something to happen, they might be appreciable features.All-in-all, if you are a big enough fan of this type of game, spend te extra to get Civilization or Europa or, my personal favourite Democracy 3.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Victoria II isn't so much a game as an alternate history simulator.  The designers were obsessive about their historical accuracy and detail... they just forgot to design any significant gameplay around it.  There are quite a few nations you can play as, but unless you play as one of the 8 great world powers, your gameplay will consist of watching your country run itself and making small insiginificant nudges in certain directions until you get invaded by one of the 8 great world powers.In summary, if you love obscure history and games that play themselves, you'll love Victoria II.

content:

												65 Hours into it and I still don't really know what I'm doing.  I've read wikia pages and the 15 scene tutorial.  I understand the concept but that's about it.  Took me probably 30 hours to figure out how the combat system works, very detailed but without an easy to use interface or even a help file that explains the differences in rows and support %'s there's no way to know what's going on.  Only reason I understand it is that wikia cleared it up.  Great concept of a game, I think the game mechanics are probably great if I could ever figure them out.  If this had a better interface or someway to explain things, I'd recommend it and possibly even give it a high score.  Since it doesn't, it's worthless to me.  2/10 for potential.  Better luck with victoria 3.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

number of helpful: 16 of 53 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												Vicky 2 is an interesting game.Covering roughly the early/mid 19th century up into the early 20th, this Paradox helping is part Europa Universalis and part Hearts of Iron but mostly something entirely different from anything else the developer has put out there. Just like the actual historical period which it covers, Vicky 2 is more or less all about industrialization and the dramatic changes taking place in the realms of technology, philosophy, politics, and culture across the globe.That being said much of the game's focus is firmly set on the domestic and the player's ability to effectively manage and build upon their chosen country's economy and government - dealing with the challenges laid before them by foreign powers or groups within the nation-state itself.Despite being fairly in line with Paradox's other grand strategy games I just couldn't quite get into this one and I doubt most others will as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 33 people (6%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Why 'Victoria Revolutions' is better than 'Victoria 2'?I played the USA and there wasn't a US-Mexican War and the Civil War started in 1852. Not against the Confederate States of America - mind you - but against a fantasy faction called 'Free State of America' located around the Great Lakes Region (Detroit).WTF? Why do the developers have the audacity to call this game 'Victoria 2'? They should have called it 'Stellaris 2' because it is set in a different (fantasy) universe - what history is concerned!After this disaster - before I would uninstall the whole bundle - I gave 'Victoria Revolutions' a shot: The US-Mexican War caught me by surprise and unprepared, so I lost it and lost all my prestige! - Why is this a good thing, you may ask? Because it not only taught me to become a better player of this particular game, it also taught me something about history. Because after I failed, I did some research about the US-Mexican War (the causes, how it was conducted, etc.) ... which made me a more educated person!Paradox Games - if you read this: Yes - improve the UI and the graphics, that is all very nice and laudable. But - please - don't destroy the game by robbing it from historical accuracies!!! I know, you wanted to give the players more freedom but does the players really want so much freedom which only leads to a bunch of silliness?Please, please, please - next time make a game which is more historical accurate - not less!!! After all - restrictions are a good thing!

content:
Posted: March 9, 2013
												DO you love the fast-paced world of financing? Then you're in for a treat! Post-Industrialism Budget Simulator II (aka Victoria II) Is a wonderful game where managing your expenditure becomes a breath-taking virtual experience. Pick any country you want and determine their tax system; give your capitalists a free ride with the comprehensive tax system, while your bleed your proletarians dry. Struggle to maintain the perfect balance between your industrial subsidides, traiffs, and national expenditure. Forget about building an army and taking over Europe as Supreme Armchair dictator, this game will have you too busy frantically avoiding bankruptcy to concern yourself with such matters! Yep, Post-Industrialism Budgent Simulator II is a must have for the aspiring predatory lendor in your family!

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Summer 2013 - I bought this game and didn't really know what to think of it as I couldn't largely get into it, possibly due to not understanding how the game works politically and with regards to industrialisation, nevertheless while campaigns were going good I won't say I didn't enjoy them. But during this time I was slightly ill and didn't really feel like learning anything new because my brain just couldn't handle it,Now go to 2014! I've spent hours upon this game and will probably spending more after taking a bit of a break from campaigns, I absolutely adore this game and how in-depth it actually is, without becoming too cumbersome, a sort of happy middle-ground between Europa Universalis 3 and Hearts of Iron 3. I would absolutely recommend this title to anyone who has a liking for grand strategy, or perhaps even for someone who is pioneering the genre for the first time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Overall though I found the game enjoyable. There were only a few things that I found annoying (which are corrected in newer Paradox games). I played this game as the US and spent a large portion of my time at speed 5. One of the greatest changes between Victoria II and EU4 or CK2 is the ability to hide messages. I don't care that a certain county now has a nitroglycerin or the Copperheads are planning something, there's no reason that a dictator/president would be given that sort of information. Definitely need to know when someone's declared war on me, but otherwise, I find a lot of the popups to be annoying.The amount of rebellions was also extremely annoying. I know I'm playing the US and the CSA is formed, but I spent most of the Civil War fighting the Jacobite (and several other) rebels into submission. Although the Civil War began in ~1858 I didn't finally put the nail in the coffin until 1872.The election part of the game was interesting as it allows the player to manipulate who is going to win the election with no downside fo them. I am certainly still a noob at this game and will probably put in another 20 or so hours to at least learn the game.tl;dr: I enjoyed this game and will carry on playing. Unfortunately, my friends suck and don't like these games, but I continue to recommend them on deaf ears 8/10.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2013
												Begining in the early 19th century, the game lets you choose any country that was in the world at that time to play as.  Any country; ranging from The United States to Abu Dabhi or Liberia.  Once in the game, you are only given a map interface and a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of tabs.  Through this map and jumbled mess of tabs you manage your country.  Not fun right?  Wrong, when given almost unlimited oppurtunity in one of the most advanced strategy games ever, a lot of fun can be had.  The game is most fun when you give yourself a goal and work for it.  Want to begin the game and establish the actual boundaries of the United States? you can do that.  Want to form the Soviet Union and its iron curtain even before 1910?  You can do that.  Want to form germany?  You can do that.  Want to make a communist Brazil and establish it as a world power?  You can do that too.  The game is unparralleled in its complexity and earns its "Grand Strategy" title.

												This game is a hidden gem of paradox. It is much harder to get into than Europa Universalis or Crusader Kings but when you manage to get the basics on control, you will find yourself days and night playing creating the best country the world has ever seen.However, this game is less about exploration and warfare than it is about politics and the general population.The game lets you play any country in the world and lets you decide what to do. You gain points by research, military power, economic power and the wellfare of your country. At the end of the last year, the country with the highest score, technically wins. But you could always ignore that and make your own goals.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												I love being able to play a game focused on world events 100 years prior to WW2, it lets you get great insight into how the World wars came about and how a lot of the foundations for other countries around the world came to be. Even though the game isn't 100% historically correct, it still tries to implement a lot of the big events that happened in the world between 1836 - 1936. You can take control of any country you want, be it an already Great Power, or perhaps a secondary power that wishes to achieve Great Power status or even a lesser developed country from the more remote parts of the world, which can perhaps even achieve Great Power status. The game is very varied, the great powers are always going to be more predominent in the worlds affairs but even great powers can fall to their knees sometimes. The micro-management of everthing from factories, to the economy, to the politics, influencing other countries, as well as focusing on military production, is very in-depth and has a steep learning curve, but once mastered, can make the game so much more enjoyable. I really recommened buying the 2 dlc expansions for Victoria II, they add so much to everything in the game, and they iron out heaps of bugs. The Heart of Darkness expansion is particulary good, it adds the "Crisis Mode" to the game, which just adds a whole new level of diplomatic and militaristic events to the game. Overall, the game is great, and there is plenty of replayability to the game as you will always be wanting to go back and perhaps try a slightly different tactic to change the future of the world! I give it a 9/10, the game can get quite memory/hard drive intensive as the game goes on and world powers suddenly have massive militaries to command. I recommend 8gb of ram for this game and if you have an ssd, even better!

												Victoria 2 is the best grand strategy game out there. The POP system is awesome, simulating EVERY adult male in the world, and the era it simulates is one of the most turbulent of mankind. It's perfect? By no means. That would be Victoria 3.IF WE HAD IT, GODDAMMIT PARADOX

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Having played some other titles by the dev before, I wanted ot start with someplace small and out of the way just to get a handle on the mechanics, you know. Anyway, after an enjoyable 3 day learning curve, I initiated land reforms and encouraged immigration. This seems to have caused a civic upswell that resulted in terminal diarreha for half of my population due to a high flow of sewage/pollution without any infrastructure to handle the increases. This unfortunately caused my coffee harvest to fall short because no one could help with the harvest because they coudn't stop pooping... economic depression was all that remained for the survivors of "the brown tide". Not too long after this, Columbia invaded me to teach America a lesson (I had agreed to help in a war because I was really far away and figured it was a nice gesture to an old ally). Anyway, after they slaughtered my tribesmen with modern, western weapons, I sued for peace and started to rebuild from scratch. To achieve economic austerity suitable to this phase; I cut all funding to the clergy and education services (my army expenditures already being rather diminished, after all). This helped to keep my people subdued and ignorant while I worked to manually pump industries back up - then I realised that near-40 years had passed in game and I was half as well off as when I started - and unarmed. I vowed never to make land reforms a priority for my governments so soon in primitive locations going forward. Rebooted and started playing the same country again. This time I have invested in experimental railroads instead of land reforms first off... this way there will be a way to quickly remove excesses of waste and bodies in the future incase I f*** up again. 9/10 would recommed accidental poop plague game fail

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Much like Hearts of Iron III, this game is exceptionally complex (I've owned it for 2 years and am still finding new things out) and some fiddling around with verifying the game cache and whatnot before it can work seems almost a universal experience. HOWEVER, there are plenty of places where you can learn the ropes of this game and once you do it will prodive a functionally inexaustable source of entertainment. Keen historians like me will frown at the appearance of WW1 French General Ferdinand Foch in 1840, or the fact that the UK seems hardwired to have 80 years of consecutive Conservative governments without player intervention (what is the Victorian era without Gladstone?), or the bizarre insistance of the Portugese to race like hellfire to conquer the Zulus and Zanzibar makes recreating the British Empire highly awkward, but these are tiny nitpicks. March west as the United States, smash France and form Germany as Prussia, break Prussia's back as France, lead the scattered German states as Austria, fly the Union flag across every continent as the British and loom menacingly over Europe, the Middle-East and Asia as the Russian Bear. Buy this game, and enjoy!

												This game is another home run from Paradox Interactive.  It is a very compelling history of the early-mid 19th to 20th centuries.  The depth of the game can be a steep learning curve, but once you've learned how to do a few things (and it took me quite a few YouTube tutorials before I really understood some of the concepts) it is quite addictive.   The only other game I've had as many "OMG it's 4AM" moments with was Civilization (any version).  I can't recommend this game highly enough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Between 1836 and 1936 in real world we see:Industrialization and the resulting change in social structure;The great war and the resulting changes in world map;Rise of all kinds of ideologies, from communism to fascism;Rise of the USA;Unification of Germany and Italy;Scramble for Africa;and so on. If you want to pick a 100 year period with the most "The world has gone mad" moments, this might be it.Now on to the game.Is it fun? Yes, I think so!Is it historically accurate? Well, it depends. It replicates some historical events well enough, but the why of it is completely off (for example, prussia needs a franco-prussian war to form germany in this game, but that's because they need alsace lorraine)What's the most impressive thing about the game? The economic/pop model. I wouldn't call it realistic, but it's so complete. Everything comes from somewhere and goes somewhere!Would I recommend it? Yes because it's fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												            Victoria 2 is a fantastic game and I've spent way too much time on this game; that's what Victoria is all about. My main complaint with the game at first was the how unwieldy it was to learn the basic concepts like industry, however it was fixed with many, many hours of testing. My second complaint is that by around 1880 on there isn't much to do other than blindly conquer other nations. My final complaint is that colonizing in the Heart of Darkness expansion sometimes lies about how close my naval bases are.The Best part about this game is the sweet feeling you get when your counties military demolishes france's military. 10/10

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Between 1836 and 1936 in real world we see:Industrialization and the resulting change in social structure;The great war and the resulting changes in world map;Rise of all kinds of ideologies, from communism to fascism;Rise of the USA;Unification of Germany and Italy;Scramble for Africa;and so on. If you want to pick a 100 year period with the most "The world has gone mad" moments, this might be it.Now on to the game.Is it fun? Yes, I think so!Is it historically accurate? Well, it depends. It replicates some historical events well enough, but the why of it is completely off (for example, prussia needs a franco-prussian war to form germany in this game, but that's because they need alsace lorraine)What's the most impressive thing about the game? The economic/pop model. I wouldn't call it realistic, but it's so complete. Everything comes from somewhere and goes somewhere!Would I recommend it? Yes because it's fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												NOTE; I play a lot in offline mode so my hours may not properly relfect how time I have spent playing this gameVictoria II is an alternate history strategy game taking place from 1836 to 1936, covering a century of some of the most drastic change in human history. It has deep politcal and diplomatic systems, but its economic system is the most relalistic I have ever seen in a strategy game. This game is not going to please everyone, but for those willing to master the difficulty curve will find an incredibly fun Expirence.]Graphics and SoundThe graphics are pretty average for when this game came out. (2010) They are not beautiful but they clearly convey what is going on. The map clearly shows all sorts of information, depending on what veiw you are in, and the simplicity of the graphics allows you to grasp what is going on at a glance.The music is entirly subjective. If you enjoy grand classical music, you will probably love the sound track. Even though I am not a huge fan of classical music, I found myself huming along. However ,if you hate this kind of music, you may just want to play something else. The music will however will be enjoyable to most. It fits the the theme of the game very well and definalty adds to the gameplay, especially when you the music changes when you are at war. Sound effects are average for the genre.GameplayThis game is similar to other Paradox strategy games such as Crusader Kings and Europa Universallis, with a number of big changes.This game has one of the best economic simulations that has ever appeared in a strategy game. It very accurately simulates rises and falls in prices of consumer goods, raw materials and militiary goods., and how they effect everyday people. It very well ties this into the rest of the gameplay, with your industries, farms factories, tax income, citizen's happiness and even your army depending on how well you manage your economy. This of course leads to wide variety of different strategies for managing it, and lots of realistic gameplay. However, it has a steep learning curve, and it can be a struggle for new players to figure it out.The political system is also interesting as it requires the player to balence the need to have a specific party in power to acomplish his goals, and the fact that has the people become more conscience to the world around them, they vote more often for the party they believe in. THis can hinder reforms or industrial growth. Elections are an interesting to guide your citizens toward certain parties and ideas. You can even become a communist, fashist or anarchist government if they get elected, or rebel and take over your captial.One of the most interesting features of diplomacy is the sphereing system. It leads to competition over the third world which can get pretty hetic. The crises and sphereing systems can convince superpowers to act on a smaller countires behalf which makes this the most interesting Paradox grand strategy game to play as a small country.Military is probably the weakest part of Victoria II. You can research a number of different technologies several different units to give you an edge. However, massive conquests are few and far between. It is much more difficult than EUIV or CKII to capture and keep territory. The AI is fairly good at diplomacy, but has horrible strategy during wars. They tend to break their armies into tiny units and pursue hit and run attacks. The most important thing to remember is that in Victoria your army and conquests are there to fuel your industry and economy, unlike a lot of stradegy game which are the other way round. The point is that miliary is not the biggest focus although it is still an important one.Finally if you are are really agresive and repidly take over territory you will quickly be routed by the world powers. You have been warned.Some Other things to mentionI highly recomend getting the two expansion packs, Heart of Darkness and A House Divided. They improve the gameplay quite a lot, improving colonization, war and palying as the U.S, among other things. The other DLC can improve your play expirence depending on how hisorically acurate/detailed you want your game. They do not change the actual gameplay so pick them up if you really enjoyed the game and they are on saleIMPORTANT This game is hard. If you are new to high strategy games. I recomend you try Europa Universallis first, simply becuase it has a better UI and much simpler systems.]ConclusionThis is one of the best strategy games availible on steam right now. It is wonderfully complex and those who enjoy learing how the game works or who simply want to expirience an alternate history of the Victorain era should pick this up.Rating9/10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Obviously based on my time spent with this game I enjoyed playing it, but there's too many flaws for me to recommend this at full price.Let's start with diplomacy. It sucks. The AI will constantly abandon you in wars unless they're inside your sphere of influence regardless of their opinion of you or your enemy. In addition, the diplomatic feedback is incredibly non-specific and results are entirely percentile based instead of a system that weighs the positive and negative factors to produce a yes or no answer. This is frustrating when the player is trying to form an alliance to survive as a weaker country. Does the Ottoman Empire want to keep Spanish and French influence outside of North Africa? Maybe. I can understand the theory behind this (after all, what government knows exactly what other governments are thinking?) but in practice it leads to silly things like an alliance being accepted three months later with LOWER diplomatic relations than the previous offer. I do like political spheres as a game mechanic, but it seems odd that a 'friendly' nation with 200 relations would reject alliance offers or military access requests.Warfare in Victoria 2 is handled fairly well, but it's difficult to tell at a glance what an enemies army tech level is until after you're already in combat. I don't really have any comments to make about it other than that it works and is decently fun to do. Economic management in any system that uses capitalists to build factories is incredibly annoying. In an age of planes, trains, and automobiles, an aspiring businessman will instead invest in a sailboat factory. Encouraging certain industries can help avoid this but it is by no means a total solution and doesn't actually prevent ♥♥♥♥♥♥ factories from being built. The projected income is virtually worthless as the amount never matches actual income and also doesn't include overseas upkeep costs. The government and social reforms work for the most part, except for in systems that allow full citizenship of all ethnicities. I conquered part of China with a liberal government, and because of the demographic change a conservative government was elected largely in part due to the Chinese vote. The new government prevented Chinese citizens from voting and they got upset about losing the right to vote. ALL OF MY WAT. The rebel system is far too vague about when rebels will actually spawn and supression points are worthless. The AI is terrible at managing countries. Small armies of 1-3 stacks will suicide into groups of 200 stacks for no apparent reason and uncivilized countries will sometimes have an absurd number of beuarucrats and manage their populations needs so poorly a province can drop to 1 citizen. Countries that never enter a single war will go bankrupt multiple times. They'll fight over sphering a tiny country while ignoring larger, more valuable targets. Overall, Victoria 2 can be very fun but it lacks in some of its most important features which forces you to use workarounds. If that doesn't bother you go ahead and make a purchase, but don't pay full price for this game if you're not already a fan of the genre. Victoria 2 relies heavily on management of your economy and alliances to do well. The problem is many of these factors are simply out of the player's influence unless you use console commands to cheat. Vanilla Victoria 2 is not very good and each DLC makes the game much better, but locks the fun behind a paywall. TL;DR: Buy the collection if it's on sale, otherwise hold off until it does.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Don't let the playtime fool you. I pirated this a long time ago (yeah, I know it's bad, but I eventually purchased it obviously), but i've played roughly over 300 hrs in this masterpiece. This game goes extremely in depth with Economy and Diplomacy being the focus points. One can definitely get lost in all the sliders and diplomacy (still trying to get England to like me as #1 in the world)... but after a while you get a lot of what the game is trying to accomplish, and that is when your country will flourish. Diplomacy:This game uses a "sphere" system in which if you get a country into your sphere, you become the primary target in terms of trade (basically, you get all of the trade the country offers for a relatively cheap price). The game also uses a "Crisis" system in which when a Crisis Temperature in a region hits 100.. it's all out war with the belligerants that consist mostly of GP (Great Powers).Speaking of GP... having a lot of GP's in your alliance as a weak nation is perfect (if you don't allow yourself to get sphered too quickly... i'm looking at you France). If you are a great power yourself, at the start of the game you're allowed only one GP, and if you're Prussia, you're basically screwed since France usually allies with Russia, and GB is willing to work with you at the beginning, then abandon you when you get too powerful... and then look to always declare war on you. Coming to think of it... resembles a lot like RL GB. All nations have a "Point System" that is divided into 3 values: "Military Power", "Prestige", and "Industrial Power".Military Power: Points that dictate how much power your military has (takes into account technology, and number of Units/ and mobilized units)Prestige: How well your country has done since the start of your campaign (Note: If you have a high Prestige, countries are willing to do deals with you much easier, and automatically generates "Sphere Points" to all countries. Industrial Power: This is the most important part that will likely be the reason why you're rich, or why you're poor. The more Industry, the more money you can make from producing goods, and selling them.Also, for Diplomacy... if you've ever played EU4 before this, then you are likely reminded of the "AE". Same applies here, but instead called Infamy. Infamy here however, will affect whether or not your allies will stay your allies... bare in mind when you go on a conquering spree xD. If you conquer too much too fast... you'll likely find yourself in a "Containment War" which basically means all the GP's that are not your allies will come crashing down on you (doesn't matter if you're focusing on the other regions of the world, so bare that in mind too).Economy: If you were paying attention to your industry and pop (population) early in the game, you will almost always succeed in this. If you didn't go moblizing and losing all of your male populations, then there will always be men in factories (notice, when you mobilize, it's taking men out of the factories to fight in your war... so once the war is over, immediatly demobilize to get the survivors back to work). My strategy every game is to take provinces from China very early in the game. That provides additional pop's, and if theres no work in China... your pop there will move to your mainland, which will fill up those factories really quick. Then you get a whole bunch of tax revenue aswell as extra men to fight in your wars. There's a whole bunch of stuff I didn't include because I already burned my life into both this game, and EU4... theres more detailed stuff out there, but I hoped I convinced anyone reading this to purchase this game. Happy Blobbing!

												A great thing about this game is that it's never the same game twice. You can have a game where france invades britain in the 1840s or where germany never forms because austria has taken half of it. Maybe japan never becomes a great power or the U.S. becomes communist. You just never know with this game. And I love it! It gives it endless replay value and unlike most grand strategy games i've played, there's still a lot going on even when you're not at war! It's not for everyone though, and it can be frustrating to learn, but once you know what you're doing, it's hard to find a better game like it. pros: +Endless replay value+Not boring in peacetime+Complex but not convoluted+Easy to run+In-DepthCons:-AI can be really stupid at times-Steep learning curve-Bad tutorial9/10

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Getting this game on a steam sale was an amazing Idea and I have no regrets. I think I got the full game with all relevant expansions for about $10. Regularly the game costs $20 , but the value easily dwarfs the $20 price tag. Although if you get this game yuoreally do need to get the expansions as well; so if there's a pack get it. Paradox games have filled a place in my heart of games. They're fun, informative and even replayable; Victoria 2 is no different and I'm happy of it. The game can be complicated at first, but after diving into a game head first and exploring the controls you can learn extremely quickly and even if you can't learn that way easily, just go to youtube and watch some tutorials. Pros:+Amazing Replayablility+Great UI +Challenging+Informative(Both in the game and historical events)+Dynamic(every game is different)+Low toll on the computer+Good mods+Cool population system(immagration and population growth)+Colonization gameCons:-Pretty much need the expansion packs, especially for mods-Some forms of government are extremely underpowered(communist becomes extremely hard to manage later in the game)-Occasional lodaup bugs and mod loadings; you may need to tinker to find the solution.-Shorter than Europa's base-timeline length.(mods can fix this)-Fairly high priced(with expansions, which I highly recommend to buy with the game). -limited start dates(mods can fix it, but still. Only one) I probably missed stuff, but this game is extremely addicting when you get into a game. I really recommend it for any strategy gamer and especially a paradox gamer.

												This is not an easy or easily-accessible game.  A lot of the game mechanics are not explained in the tutorials and the interface is very dry and sometimes a bit deep and complicated.  This is the Dwarf Fortress of strategy games, with no actual victory conditions and a cliff-like learning curve.  All that said, when you do master it, you'll be sucked in like you wouldn't believe.  If Europa Universalis is too tame and simple, then this is your game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I bought this game on the steam christmas sale. I have a bit to say about it both good and bad*I only have the vanilla game, I have yet to grab the DLC*Grand Strategy Games:This is a genre that focuses a lot on complex and/or large strategy games that mostly involve a political simulator. Victoria 2 is a grand strategy that puts you in the shoes of the leader of any country from 1836 to 1936, the cusp of the second world war. This was known as the industial era for many countries and was also the time the British Empire had reached the hight of it's power. The Grand Campain:This is the main game. You start in 1831 and you can select any country that was around during that period. From there, you will make many decisions. Each country plays differently usually because of location, what state the country is in and the different government and ruling party types. Of course, some countries are stronger than others, so there is a ranking system for the world. Great Powers are the top 8 countries. Theen the secondary powers. Followed by civilized nations and uncivilized nations. Parts of the world are also still uncolinized like parts of Canada and most of Africa. Some countries like Germany, Italy and Norway as well as many more countries have still not been formed or are yet to gain independece from larger empires like the British.Pros--Large list of countries to play as.-Real events such as the American Civil War.-A good UI that conveys all the information needed about your country.- Can colonize to expand your lands (Only Great Powers and Secondary Powers may colonize)-Choices define what makes your empire. They are important. Most choices have advantages and disadvantages to choose your choices wisely.-Can have rebellions in your country if peopleget too militant.-Play at your own pace. Fast forwarding and pausing the game at any time.-Lots of techs to research and inventions to discover, giving you different kinds of advantages.-A decent tutorial to get you going.Cons--A very steep learning curve if you are new to these kind of games.(Does have a decent tutorial though)-AI has a few problems sometimes, could have been fixed with DLC though.- Bad multiplayer, it's hard to join other people and you can't just quick join random people. To join someone, you must register on the Paradox fourms or use a virtual network like Hamachi.-Hard to keep track of world events. You can set certain catagory events to pop up if you like but a lot of events wont pop up by deafault, they just happen.Can't think of what else to say about the game other than it's fun to see where you can go by just choosing some interesting countries and trying to develope them into whatever you want. For example, I played as britain and released Ireland from the british empire and then decided to play as Ireland since I am Irish ha. I began to tax people severly to improve my econemy and so I began buying weapon parts. I began to build transport ships and recruit and army and then I invaded Malaysia. Tried to invade surrounding nations but the world quickly turned on me. America, Russia, Britain, France all declared war on me and they quicky arrived on Irish soil. The purpose of the war was to contain me and I agreed within a couple of months and so I lost a huge portion of my army. Oh well... I got Ireland pretty far in terms of inustry in the end with a booming economy as well. I got from rank 55 to 30 in the end but oh well. Now, I am ploting my revenge and my plan for world domination xDVerdict, 8/10. Pretty damn good, but has a few problems.*Again, note that I have none of the DLC for this game. The game might easily be a 9/10 with a couple of it's problems fixed*

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Conclusion: While having had a nation in tears, it's the most fun Paradox game I played.So I started as the Netherlands, full of some good expansionist spirit, and began my conquests in Asia but had no idea about infamy amongst nations or why protectorates are better than conquests.. so just into my second expansion, I got cut to size ('contain') by England forcing me to half my armies,pay 33% tax in repairs and raise no new armies. Guess what happened next.. standing there all naked...mother Russia came knocking for the same: A nation in tears.So I did what any other 19th century ruler would have done.. go online... watch some let's play youtubes, learn about factories, profits and how to get in the top 8 of nations (fun).. and that a low tax rate for the wealthy truly is an inspiring solution..  So right now I've got Holland at no.7 nipping at the heals of Austria in pos 6  in 1849 (to be continued) and I'm having a ball to get the 'free' elections to play out right :)Summary- For me, the most enjoyable Grand Strategy game from Paradox  (above HOI2/DH,CK2,HOI3 and EUx) especially because I don't need to micro manage everything.- Great interface, after the initial learning the concepts hurdle- Decent Graphics with great overlays- Great Music as it does not wear out- You'll pick up entirely new insights into economics & politics- Fun!!! & Challenging- Every game turns out very differentScore for Victoria2 Heart of Darkness:9.5/10 (-0.5 because it needs two expansion packs: please just sell it as Vic2 Complete)

												I love this game so much. And yet at the same time I hate it with intense passion. It's amazing - the way it breaks you. I started playing it thinking it would be a fun romp through the Nineteenth century, conquering and colonizing every bloody ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who looked at me the wrong way. Yeah, right. In that sense it reminds me of Silent Hunter III - the only game that, I'll admit, beat me. This game put me into my place, slapped me around, and said: "Right, now THIS is how you're going to play." And I did, Expect to read a lot of guides because starting Victoria II requires preparation. And when you know how it works, well... Then you can start innovating, trying out new daring strategies.The most important thing I found out was that, though it may seem a small victory on a grand scale, it's still as important as any other. Alliances are always shifting: one decade I (as Belgium) was buddy-buddies with France fight a Dutch-Prussian coalition, the next - Germany helps to repel French invaders from my soil. The great nations themselves might suffer crippling bankruptcies rearranging the power system.It's a very hard, very fun and VERY rewarding game when you get down to it. I never thought I would be able to play it much less enjoy it. Victoria II does require determination, and study if you're not familiar with the grand strategy genre, as I was, but in the end it's worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Quite possible one of the greatest strategy games ever created. The control the player has over economics and politics is unmatched and fantastic, and the military module is quite good too. You can play as a juggernaut state from the West and carve out a giant world straddlingempire, or you can strike it ou tas a developing nation. Paradox has managed to make all of these scenarios almost equally fun. The game is quite modable, and there are huge packs that put the game in the modern world, or extend its timeline over 300 years. This game is far different from Europa Universalis or Hearts of Iron, but is different in a good way. If you are looking for more than just a military simulator or world map color changer, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Hoo boy does this game have a steep learning curve. And the Victorian era doesn't exactly excite people the way the middle ages or ancient Rome does. But if you work past that, you will have a fascinatingly exploration of an era that still defines our modern life, only now you get to set the course. Will America become a communist nation? Will France, after losing the Great War become fascist? Who will lead the world in automobile production? Have Brazil lead the scramble for Africa. Have Egypt form a pan-national Arab empire. Dismantle the British Empire. Make Canada the 51st state.The only limit is your imagination (and RGO's).

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Victoria II is a very linear game that takes you though the key events of the mid-1800s to the mid-1900s, such as:- The American Civil War- The Meiji Restoration of Japan- The rise and reign of terror of the Fascist Orange Free State- The Great War, including a monumental simulation of the famous "California Campaign" by the Communist forces of the Cherokee Nation- The Great Depression of 1907, where the sudden drop of the price of glass destroyed the world economy beyond repair- That time when the Chinese Empire westernized and proceeded to completely slaughter the combined armies of France, the Netherlands, and HungaryHighly recommended for those of us who pine for a "history" game that is truly historical.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Victoria II is a very niche game in my opinion. This is not for everyone. The combat is basically a combination of luck and stats and is very frustrating so don't come into this game expecting anything like StarCraft.As an avid lover of history though this is basically my wet dream come true. Victoria II focuses on the Post Napoleon Era of the world. This game allows you to play as basically everything country that existed between the early 19th century and the 1920s. I have never seen a game that allowed me to play as Belgium or Colombia or Hawaii. The point is to take your country from an early industrial state to being an imperial empire.You have to build your nation, your economy, your foreign relations, and your military. Either hope to be one of the eight main superpowers or pray to at least maintain your independence. What it most interesting is that there doesn't seem to be a way to actually "lose". When my government was overthrown I thought I lost, but the game kept going. Except we were communists and new social policies were in place and my ecomony was wrecked from the civil war. Which is interesting mechanic. The objective is to be the top great power and you are competing with over a 100 other nations that may come and go. Mods add even more.Victoria II works for me because I like the management aspect and it focuses on my favorite era of history and allows me to play anywhere in the world. I have to plan my economy and expansion and go to war carefully since it can cost you prestige, cost you a portion of your workforce if they get slaughtered, and drain your economy (like a real nation).It's not a perfect game, but I have fun and maybe you will too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Paradox Studios grand strategy games span the history of the world in a more-or-less continuous order; at time of writing, I consider the main series to be...Crusader Kings II (769 - 1453)Europa Universalis IV (1444 - 1821)Victoria II (1836 - 1936)Hearts of Iron III (1936 - 1948)So Victoria II sits near the end of that progression, covering the fall of the Ottoman Empire, the American Civil War, the growth of Japan (and industrialisation in general), and notably, the First World War (if it happens!). It's a period where huge political shifts occur in the power structure of the world, the first major colonisation pushes are made, and eventually, the scramble for Africa. You can take control of LITERALLY any country and pilot them through this period, building railroads, factories, battleships, and influencing policies, political parties, and social movements. You can grow your country into one of the Great Powers of the world, and establish protectorates, bring other countries into your sphere of influence, and found colonies.This one game, with its incredible scope, is really many different games in one; playing America (initially a slave state) will be a largely different experience to playing, say, China, which will yet again be different to playing a tiny country like Panama. I've had most fun playing the 'middle' states, like Persia, Japan, and Australia (after devolving it from the British Empire). While it's hard to rock the boat at the top of the great powers list, I've also had fun playing France, making major in-roads into the nascent Germany, and conquering Switzerland. Alliances can bring about amusing consequences (like, in my France game, Equadorian Sardinia??), and national decisions can create large diversions from history.All this aside, bear in mind this is a Paradox strategy game. Which means, if you haven't played one before, be prepared for a LONG game, with potentially a lot of waiting. Colonisation, a really key part of the game for great powers, isn't possible until over 20 hours in, at least. The menus are many, and the choices opaque. I highly recommend watching a Let's Play for this game before you attempt it. Once you've learnt to play it, however, it's a very rewarding experience.It's not for everyone, but if you like long, deep Grand Strategy games, give a try.

I've had this game for a year and a half (Not on Steam) and I still play it almost everyday, and while it has a steep learning curve (like most paradox games) learining to play the game is highly rewarding. This game is a giant sandbox, it allows you to play any existing nation from 1836-1935, you can even play as other nations as they are created.  While the Vanilla game is great, I would highly recommend getting the 'Victoria 2 Collection' As the 2 DLC really spice up gameplay and improve the game itself. THis game is not one you can beat on a day like I said it has very long games, with various political party's to choose for your nation, and infinite possibilites. All in all this is in my top 5 favorite games, and I highly recommend it, despite the price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												When I explain this game to friends, I always call it the Otto von Bismark simulator. I think this is perhaps the best way to sum up the role of the player in this simulation of the period between 1836-1936.In contrast with other titles from Paradox that people may have played, this game has a much lighter focus on war, and a far greater and deeper focus on internal politics and social movements than any other Paradox title. Detailed data on industry, demographics, trade, and government policies are all there to be manipulated for the advancement of the goals of your people, or alternatively, the goals of their ruler. The player truly is the arbiter between a ruler and his people, and decides the political outcome for any state in the whole wide world, by the end of the session. This makes up greatly for the notable fact that this is the shortest of true Paradox "grand campaign" games (since I don't consider Hearts of Iron to be one). The fact that only 100 years is playable is far outshone by the amount of activities to partake in as you play them.Now, I should note, for players of newer Paradox titles (as I myself was when I picked up V2), that the war AI is quite inferior to that of the more recent titles (particularly the fantastic EU IV AI), and graphics are also much less immersive. However, in my opinion, the sheer volume of social and political management you have access to during "downtime" completely demolishes a sole reliance on good graphics and war gameplay. In fact, if you couple the fact that V2 is a fully developed game that is not undergoing constant mechanical reinvention and the fact that it does not suffer from the great DLC bloat of those newer titles, you, like me, might come to find that Victoria 2 is the greatest Paradox grand strategy title.Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												It's the mother of all empire-builders.If you're at all interested in the period or just want to try your hand at running a country , this is the game for you. Economics, politics, diplomacy, colonization, and war, it's all there. The game does require a learning curve and depending on the country, it can be slow at times.However building your economy from nothing and dominating your rivals is immensely satisfying. Unlike the EU series this isn't a war game, war is always an option but as the century goes on you'll find war increasingly costly unless you beat down your foes at the start.Be sure to get the expansions, especially Heart of Darkness as it adds a lot to colonization and diplomacy. Crises in particular are great, if you're not careful you can drag Europe into total war over some petty imperial squabbles, not unlike how WW1 began in real life.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 28, 2011
												Victoria II is an epic strategy game that trancends the 19th century, in to the dawn of the 20th. It is as neither expansive as Europa Universalis III, nor as in-depth as Hearts of Iron III, yet it manages to capture perfectly a time period of industrializatoin and expansion. The combat system is a hybrid of EU3s simplistic 3 unit-type system, and the depth of HoE3. The government and economy seem to be the focus of this game, as your main difficulties are supplying your citizens with their needs while establishing a powerful industrial economy. This can be easy or difficult depending on your nation of choice, as you can choose to play as any nation in existence on January 1, 1836. If I were to give this game a rating out of 10, I would give it an 8.5. I would recommend this game to any hard-core strategy fan who is looking for an in-depth yet accessible game.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												In my opinion, this game is the best way to start playing Paradox grand strategy games. At first, game interface is easier to understand. Importan thing about the game is industrialism, you have to adapt your country, your citizens to consume much and keep them continue their life happy. Research points are also very important, increasing literacy rate of your country has directly effect your developement agaist rival countries(nobody wants to lose war with 100.000 soldiers against 50.000:) After building a strong industry, you need to supply factories mostly from overseas like Far East and Africa. Colonization is also very important issue, after mid game a Great Power country should have some colonies from overseas, Africa is easy to connect from Europe even for American countries. I suggest this game to people who has interest for 19th century history or pre WW's age how most of today's superpowers begin their journey(adapting new policies or form strong nation) to split from rest of the world. A full game will last around 30 hours of gameplay but time will change drastically concerning about your game style.Personally I recommend this game to strategy lovers especially whose want to start playing Paradox Interactive grand strategy games. After then you will get addicted to grand strategy sub genre games like Crusader Kings, Europa Universalis and Hearts of Iron. My point is 8.5/10 to this lovely game:)

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Overall though I found the game enjoyable. There were only a few things that I found annoying (which are corrected in newer Paradox games). I played this game as the US and spent a large portion of my time at speed 5. One of the greatest changes between Victoria II and EU4 or CK2 is the ability to hide messages. I don't care that a certain county now has a nitroglycerin or the Copperheads are planning something, there's no reason that a dictator/president would be given that sort of information. Definitely need to know when someone's declared war on me, but otherwise, I find a lot of the popups to be annoying.The amount of rebellions was also extremely annoying. I know I'm playing the US and the CSA is formed, but I spent most of the Civil War fighting the Jacobite (and several other) rebels into submission. Although the Civil War began in ~1858 I didn't finally put the nail in the coffin until 1872.The election part of the game was interesting as it allows the player to manipulate who is going to win the election with no downside fo them. I am certainly still a noob at this game and will probably put in another 20 or so hours to at least learn the game.tl;dr: I enjoyed this game and will carry on playing. Unfortunately, my friends suck and don't like these games, but I continue to recommend them on deaf ears 8/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Don't let the playtime fool you. I pirated this a long time ago (yeah, I know it's bad, but I eventually purchased it obviously), but i've played roughly over 300 hrs in this masterpiece. This game goes extremely in depth with Economy and Diplomacy being the focus points. One can definitely get lost in all the sliders and diplomacy (still trying to get England to like me as #1 in the world)... but after a while you get a lot of what the game is trying to accomplish, and that is when your country will flourish. Diplomacy:This game uses a "sphere" system in which if you get a country into your sphere, you become the primary target in terms of trade (basically, you get all of the trade the country offers for a relatively cheap price). The game also uses a "Crisis" system in which when a Crisis Temperature in a region hits 100.. it's all out war with the belligerants that consist mostly of GP (Great Powers).Speaking of GP... having a lot of GP's in your alliance as a weak nation is perfect (if you don't allow yourself to get sphered too quickly... i'm looking at you France). If you are a great power yourself, at the start of the game you're allowed only one GP, and if you're Prussia, you're basically screwed since France usually allies with Russia, and GB is willing to work with you at the beginning, then abandon you when you get too powerful... and then look to always declare war on you. Coming to think of it... resembles a lot like RL GB. All nations have a "Point System" that is divided into 3 values: "Military Power", "Prestige", and "Industrial Power".Military Power: Points that dictate how much power your military has (takes into account technology, and number of Units/ and mobilized units)Prestige: How well your country has done since the start of your campaign (Note: If you have a high Prestige, countries are willing to do deals with you much easier, and automatically generates "Sphere Points" to all countries. Industrial Power: This is the most important part that will likely be the reason why you're rich, or why you're poor. The more Industry, the more money you can make from producing goods, and selling them.Also, for Diplomacy... if you've ever played EU4 before this, then you are likely reminded of the "AE". Same applies here, but instead called Infamy. Infamy here however, will affect whether or not your allies will stay your allies... bare in mind when you go on a conquering spree xD. If you conquer too much too fast... you'll likely find yourself in a "Containment War" which basically means all the GP's that are not your allies will come crashing down on you (doesn't matter if you're focusing on the other regions of the world, so bare that in mind too).Economy: If you were paying attention to your industry and pop (population) early in the game, you will almost always succeed in this. If you didn't go moblizing and losing all of your male populations, then there will always be men in factories (notice, when you mobilize, it's taking men out of the factories to fight in your war... so once the war is over, immediatly demobilize to get the survivors back to work). My strategy every game is to take provinces from China very early in the game. That provides additional pop's, and if theres no work in China... your pop there will move to your mainland, which will fill up those factories really quick. Then you get a whole bunch of tax revenue aswell as extra men to fight in your wars. There's a whole bunch of stuff I didn't include because I already burned my life into both this game, and EU4... theres more detailed stuff out there, but I hoped I convinced anyone reading this to purchase this game. Happy Blobbing!

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												This review goes for all the Paradox games I've played so far. Victoria II is what I call a National Strategy game (care for your country of choice and Expand.) Crusders II is a Kingdom (more personal involvement and expand), Europe Universialis IV is a County Strategy for room to expand as well. Victoria II is a great game to play, even though I'm havin my butt handed to me I play in Texas So I'm by myself and I always have Mexico annexing Texas. I only have 8 troops to start with. It's easy to get going in The USA part, but by urself it's a different ball game. Anyone who enjoys these types of games Medieval games that is (I'm a medieval junkie) will enjoy Victoria II. Game play is the same as Crusaders II and the rest. You deal with elections, set up factories, build boats, navy and Amry troops. Keep or abolish salvery. by a Demicratic, Whig, or Conservative Party each with there pro's and con's for each party. Again if you like games like this I recommend Victoria II.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												THE best strategy game of all time. If you don't like this game you're not a strategy gamer. Victoria 2 gives the player unprecedented control over the political and economic aspects of countries in the Victorian Era. On top of that, there are hundreds of nations to chose from and form, covering all of the nations that existed from 1839-1936. You want to be an expansionist France who longs to integrate the Wallonians and reach it's natural borders west of the Rhine? You can do that.You want to be a German Empire that's the number one country in the world industrially, with unrivaled infrastructure and vast coal reserves? You bet your♥♥♥♥♥you can.You long to unifiy the Indian people and liberate them from the British Tyranny? Go right ahead. You want to help Iran take a different approach during the Victorian Era, and to become one of the world's Great Powers? The only thing stopping you is your imagination. What are you waiting for, buy it!
