content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Already a classic from the Paradox games. It can take a while to learn and hold full grasp of all the mechanics at the beginning. But the variety of countries to play, and the different paths you can make your country can undergo make it one of the best Grand Strategy games in the market, not only in its complexity and realism but also because it's generally not too.For now my hours in the game are few in Steam, but I already have hundreds of hours of gameplay in the CD-based game I had. Forming new nations, colonizing Africa and America, industrializing, taking territory from you enemies or just liberating countries under them, passing social and liberal reform to become a democracy, or roll back such reform to return to Absolutism, your choice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Really detailed and with a wide range of things to do, countries to play as and a generally enjoyable sandbox environment. A worthy purchase for any fan of Paradox's other games like Crusader Kings 2, Hearts of Iron or Europa Universalis. Even at its normal price it's worth it but it's especially good if you (like I did) get the Victoria Collection on sale, making it an absolute steal. There are also a bunch of great mods like HPM and NWO which improve on the game (e.g. by fixing bugs) and which add new content. My biggest complaint is that it crashed on startup the first time I played it (A common problem, I have heard) but the issue is easy to fix.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												This game is pretty much the only option for a casual/intermediate level of grand strategy for the long 19th century (1836 - 1920). To enjoy this game fully you should get the 2 dlc available for it (Heart of Darkness and A House Divided), since they flesh out the period in important ways. Without them, the game can seem quite dull at times, especially when playing with a minor nation.The economic system with all the comparative difficulties in different nations in achieving a modern industrialised economy are done very well in the game. Similarly the colonization aspect is an interesting and exciting race to conquer Africa and it's resources (it is, however, handled in a very hands-off fashion without moralizing, so some may be distressed by it). The main problems in the game are the military and diplomatic sides of things. Alliances among the great nations are formed in a fairly obscure fashion, and it is difficult to get a handle on how to ensure you gain useful allies. Similarly the different international crises are quite random and don't seem to be determined by actual events in the game (for example, Poland keeps wanting to become independent, mostly from the Russian empire, but this seems to have no relation to the different revolutions or revolts that take place). Military and battle systems are not great. Battles are mostly very drawn out affairs where the person with the biggest numbers wins. There is not much drama, since you can mostly see the result of a war from the difference in initial military strenghts of the nations taking part. All in all, Victoria 2 is a good game that has some significant problems. But, as I said at the beginning of the review, it is pretty much the only option.

												My hours in this game should read about 300, but I had to launch it out of steam because of a bug.  Anyways, this lets you control a country during the most interesting time in human history, the industrial revolution.  It is a Social, economical, and political simulator.  You have to colonize Africa while keeping all those black people happy.  You have to build an industry while supplying food for your growing urban technology.  You have to keep up your trade while still promoting business in your own country.  And you have to research Cultural tech and Military tech just to stay in the game

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Stretching beyond the depth and scope of most 4X strategy games, Victoria II is the most intensive "altnerate history simulator" that I've ever played, even topping out Paradox's EU and CK series. Managing all aspects of your country including political alignment, policy reforms, managing the demands of the populace, incorporating underdeveloped or smaller countries into your sphere of influence, your military, economy, and so much more make Victoria II a remarkably engaging and rewarding experience for anyone looking for true grand strategy experience. Highly recommended, especially if you already enjoy other 4X games!

												Hoo boy does this game have a steep learning curve. And the Victorian era doesn't exactly excite people the way the middle ages or ancient Rome does. But if you work past that, you will have a fascinatingly exploration of an era that still defines our modern life, only now you get to set the course. Will America become a communist nation? Will France, after losing the Great War become fascist? Who will lead the world in automobile production? Have Brazil lead the scramble for Africa. Have Egypt form a pan-national Arab empire. Dismantle the British Empire. Make Canada the 51st state.The only limit is your imagination (and RGO's).

												Victoria II is a very linear game that takes you though the key events of the mid-1800s to the mid-1900s, such as:- The American Civil War- The Meiji Restoration of Japan- The rise and reign of terror of the Fascist Orange Free State- The Great War, including a monumental simulation of the famous "California Campaign" by the Communist forces of the Cherokee Nation- The Great Depression of 1907, where the sudden drop of the price of glass destroyed the world economy beyond repair- That time when the Chinese Empire westernized and proceeded to completely slaughter the combined armies of France, the Netherlands, and HungaryHighly recommended for those of us who pine for a "history" game that is truly historical.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												(Note: even though Steam says I have less then 1 hour played in this game, that is incorrect, as I have several hundred hours played, I just don't use Steam when playing)Victoria 2 is probably one of the best but most complicated strategy games ever made. The sheer scale and scope of it will blow your mind if you haven't played a Paradox game before (actually it still will even if you have). But once you start to understand its systems and the time period, your mind will really be expanded. The politics system and the economics alone are more detailed, realistic and complex than anything outside of a high-level supercomputer simulation (and certainly more so then any other game I know of).It is daunting to learn the complexity of this game, but fortunately you don't really need to master all the systems in order to be able to play fairly well (you can get-by without understanding everything). And the more you play the more you'll master it and, like I said, by the time you've done that you will literally be a smarter person. The game's mechanics are complex enough that you cannot really predict the outcome of things in the long run (like which countries will come to dominate), because it's all based on complex systems interactive with other complex systems to create the ultimate complexity. Which does a good job of simulating human history,The vanilla game is good, but it gets much better with mods. Of which there are lots. There's tweak mods, overhaul mods, alternate history mods, etc. But the one I would recommend for both improved gameplay and improved realism is POP Demand Mod (it's probably the closest you'll get to actually directing history).This is a game where you take a nation from the 19th century, very much into the 20th. You can industrialise as an advanced European colonial power, or start as a primitive country (like say China or Japan) and if you play right, you can race ahead and catch up and even overtake the Europeans. By the end of a game you're likely to be in a very interesting world, with Monarchies, Democracies, Fascist and Communist states fighting it out in world wars. You will never have the same end-game world in more than one playthrough, so you're creating alternate history as you go.If you're into hardcore strategy and/or history, then you've got to experience this game.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												In my opinion, this game is the best way to start playing Paradox grand strategy games. At first, game interface is easier to understand. Importan thing about the game is industrialism, you have to adapt your country, your citizens to consume much and keep them continue their life happy. Research points are also very important, increasing literacy rate of your country has directly effect your developement agaist rival countries(nobody wants to lose war with 100.000 soldiers against 50.000:) After building a strong industry, you need to supply factories mostly from overseas like Far East and Africa. Colonization is also very important issue, after mid game a Great Power country should have some colonies from overseas, Africa is easy to connect from Europe even for American countries. I suggest this game to people who has interest for 19th century history or pre WW's age how most of today's superpowers begin their journey(adapting new policies or form strong nation) to split from rest of the world. A full game will last around 30 hours of gameplay but time will change drastically concerning about your game style.Personally I recommend this game to strategy lovers especially whose want to start playing Paradox Interactive grand strategy games. After then you will get addicted to grand strategy sub genre games like Crusader Kings, Europa Universalis and Hearts of Iron. My point is 8.5/10 to this lovely game:)

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I spent many many hours on Victoria I and II in the past. it is absorbing and so incredibly detailed. While you can automate a lot of functions, if you want to master the game (esp win with the larger countries) then you'll find yourself dealing with hundreds of units and staffing & trade across vast national industries. It is worth it once you get past that sharp learning curve and you pick up a lot of history on the way! By far my favourite strategy game.

												first game, i choose to play as belgium.at the beginning everything runs smooth, a couple of wars with netherlands but i manage to win them and getting they to pay for the wars. diplomacy is good, france and great britain are my alliedeconimic and industries are going great, getting steady 50£ a day of income, with taxes below 50% and subsides fully paid. my account says 3M... yay!!slowly i become a super power, thanks to my industry.and then....everything start to fall apart, a world war breaks out, france against germany, russia against austria and all the satellite in the between. i try to take half of the netherland as they have no land army, but germany has other plans.they start the invasion, my allies france and great britain turn their backs on me and i ♥♥♥♥ed.i loose wallonie, which was my most industrialized region, forced to pay for war.i ended up the game around 1917, due to banckrupt and rebellion.CON:-there is no "resume" of the wars, so you never now the total losses in the war. i remember paradox used to have it in europa universalis 3, and i found it very interesting.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												While EU4 and CK2 have eclipsed Vicky 2 in both technical and gameplay terms, the Vicky series still fills its temporal and game style niche in the Paradox line of games.  While the newer games make Vicky 2 look outdated and unintuitive by comparison, I often miss the focus on industry and politics that the other games shy away from.  With Vicky 3 on the distant horizon, my enjoyment from its predecessor and Parodox games in general makes it an automatic preorder!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Do you like pie charts? What about the 19th century? How about the lead up to the Great War? If your answer is no to all of these please keep looking for other games. If your answer was yes then please buy this game. Victoria II (AKA Vicky 2) is one of those Paradox Interactive Grand Strategy games, the start and finish stretching from 1836 to 1936. One-hundred years of gameplay during the Victorian Era and you get to pick whichever nation you want. Do you want to form a Greater Germany with the Austrian Empire in the fold? How about an Ottoman Empire that never lost it's status in the world? What about making Texas a North American Great Power (Yes this is possible just VERY difficult)? A lot can be achieved in this game if you take the time to learn how it works.Speaking of which a lot of people seem intimidated by these sorts of games, and I really do not blame them. In the whole listings of Paradox Interactive titles this one is pretty simple compared to the later ones. That's not to say Vicky 2 is for dummies or somehow not good enough, just that it is deceptively hard. You do not need any sort of degree in geopolitics or mathematics to understand what the game is showing you. There are a lot of very good guides out there for this game and I heartily recommend the wiki for the game itself. The pie charts are easily readable and each POP (population) is easily identifiable, making knowing your citizens a lot smoother.Another thing to know is that If you want the full experience with this game make sure you buy HoD (Heart of Darkness). It fleshes out the colonisation a lot more and makes the whole Great War idea actually possible to happen in all your games. Now this does not mean you are forced into fighting these wars (Unless your nation is dead center for the war) so you can just stay out of any fighting. However doing so will cost you prestige in the eyes of the world, which if you stay on top of your military technology then you should not have much to fear. Just make sure to read up how to make good army compositions first.Lastly if you enjoy history or alternative historical situations then this game is for you. Would you like to keep the Qing Empire from falling apart? Or perhaps a communist Austria? Many, many things are very possible in this game. As of writing this game is 5 USD so if you plan to buy it now is the time. If you do I sincerely hope it is the game you are looking for. It can look daunting yes but give it a chance and you could learn quite a bit from it :)
